comments.text: I posted up a little farther down the ramp but close enough. It's a good ramp. If you're planning to get caught in Lake Louise, bring provisions though. Stores here will rip you off.

Got picked up twice in the same day at this spot in winter around 2pm and 7pm on friday. Really good, wide enough to pull over and cars are still driving slowly ! Dropped off in Banff, but could have been to Calgary with the same driver !

Quite a neat spot, though I had to wait a bit over an hour, which is longer than Quebec average for me. Maybe beacuse I started on the morning of Canada Day.

Easy to get to, $3 bus ride from the centre of Montreal. Great place to pull over, long straight stretch to get noticed from far, as though it was meant for hitching. Not so much traffic though.
Second time we get lucky here. It was dark, we thought it wouldn't work. Only 15min and someone drove us straight to Ottawa
Very nice spot. Cars have time to see you and loads of space to stop

Even better than the one the wiki site is giving. Same way to get (local buses for 2-3$) there but keep walking over the bridge (there is a bike lane). Look on your left and that's it.
It's pretty easy to get there climbing the fence at the junction with the bridge (i've done this with my 20kg backpack)
Perfect spot and your should have more cars than the previous one.
Got a ride toward Ottawa pretty quickly
Stand right on the corner of where the irving pavement lot meets the road and have a big sign saying where you want to go since people will be either going west or east. June 2025.

Hichthiked towards St Johns here in late September. If you stand next to the road make sure to have a sign with you that says where you are going as the highway splits into two. It's a great spot though, slow and a lot of traffic.

Southwards and northwards. Stop at the Big Stop and ask the people for being picked up.
It should work pretty well.
great spot. Slow traffic, lots of room to stop. Got picked up very quick.
Easy access, good visibility, slow traffic, lots of room to pull off. Most traffic will be going to Whistler or Pemberton area.
2 hikers in a big Jeep took us exactly where we wanted to go (Garibaldi Lake Trail, Rubble Creek Trailhead), we were very lucky!
Traffic is slow through town, people can pull into side streets to pick you up
Amazing spot to hitchhike, there's also a truck stop so you can try and ask around, didn't take long to get a ride with a guy all the way to Edmonton even though it was very late afternoon :)

When hitching here, I got a ride straight to Montreal after 10 minutes of waiting, so it worked out great for me. May have been just luck. There is some traffic, maybe not fluent, but you always see something going. Stand just before "no pedestrians" sign.
Not much traffic here. Still we got a ride after some time, straight to Montréal

Direction Montréal. Il you get a ride out of Quebec past the bridges, there is still sufficient traffic at this exit to get a good ride. It would seldom be directly going to Montreal, unless it's a truck, though. There is a Tim Hortons nearby for caffeine and toilets, and a truckstop.

I got three ride offers in 30min, but they were all short. I took the last one, and got skunked two ramps down. Try to only accept rides that are going to Hope or beyond. 

With the truckstop, this is a good ramp to post up on.

I posted up on the ramp, at the end of the Jersey barrier. I didn't have to wait very long. There is a big truck stop near by for provisions, and the SFX bus stops just up the road, so this is a good spot for heading east out of the lower mainland.
Very good spot to go to Québec city

Really nice spot!
The best thing : you have a free place to camp in case you dont find a lift!

Really nice spot !! 
2 gas station, busy
Plenty of space and good speeds after the lights. Road splits up ahead, so good idea to have a sign
Look for the tourist parking area on the North side. Enough for cars to pull into the parking lot for you can load up! Nelson people are nice
I hitchhiked there with Crankworkx Whistler sign and got ride within 3 minutes.
Spot with wide shoulders and lots of traffic.

Ein super Spot, um Ganges nach Süden zu verlassen ( zum Beispiel nach Fulford Harbour). Jemand hat schöne Schilder aus Holz gebastelt, auf denen die möglichen Ziele stehen. Zieht einfach euer Schild aus der Halterung an dem Masten und haltet es in die Höhe. Nach spätestens 10 min sitzt ihr in einem Auto. Saltspring ist der tramperfreundlichste Ort, an dem ich je war!!!

Pour aller vers l'EST
l'endroit est suivit d'une côte mais il y a une bonne visibilité et un accotement sécuritaire.

After been picked up from central montral ive been droped on the freeway , i juat cross to the freeway just by the dot its the exact point , as soon as i cross , a lovely young lady stop and took me all the way to quebec !
Worked fine for me 20 min to take me by the end of the prairie from where i got pick up again in 15 min wass heading to Regina

Maybe not the exact spot , but wass heading north , just opposite the bed and breakfast motel , so probably few yard up or down , so its just 100 meter aprox , u cant miss it , just the only motel , accros the rd by the little white church , but i guess is luck cause the personne who droped me her ask the parked car their and their where goind to Fort nelson where i wass going ! So pure luck , drop off drop in !
Heading north been droped pff her by a truck driver , next car within 10 min stoped and took me all the way to prophet river !
Been droped her from prince george got a quick lift to Dawson greek where i spend the night !

Its illgal but i did it and a very good spot , just as u tur right from the main tstreet to the entrance ( no curb ) went into the split concree where both go to hope  and took theleft side the one whos going straight to the freeway , less than 5 min as the entryence is really packed due to the density of traffic so car did t even had to stop he just keep rolling very slowly and waved me to jump in !

Actually the map is a bit messy anyway when u turn right at the previous juction from the main street i did walk like on the entrance of the freeway up yo the split where the right go upward and the left straight into the freeway i waited at that junction car usually slow. Due to the high density of the congestion so basicly after less than 10 min a car wave at me and he didnt had to stop i just jumped in ! Took me 350 km up i wass heading to alaska but of course wasnt expecting s traight lift l

after been droped at the border i walk up her as i initlialy start just accros the border but been told by the costum that its illegal to hitchik so i come over her , and wass a good call as 25 min later a very good canadian ( as they are ) took me all the way to Vancouver and offer me a lunch !
I was standing after the gas station  and managed to get a ride all the way to Calgary even though it was almost night time
WEST direction - enough space to pull over, cars go slow because of traffic lights, managed to get a ride in 15 mins
Pretty good place if you're heading west, enough space to pull over and the traffic is really good even in late afternoon
Près des ponts pour prendre l'autoroute 20. Juste devant le ultramar où il y a deux entrées pour la cours. Permet donc une bonne visibilité et du temps aux conducteurs-rices pour nous prendre.
so you are on the ferry....ask for rides!! im sure one of those guys won't mind
Last on ramp before the Ottawa-Montreal split. Lamp posts and lots of space to stop, gaz station and restaurants nearby
Direct ride to Montreal via Laval
Plenty of place to stop, fairly passing on ramp with shops around in Montreal direction.
Good spot. Plenty of space to pull over.

I have hitchhiked north from this spot multiple times. Even with two people I never had to wait more than 30 minutes. Go all the way to the gas station or stop even before, so that people may see you earlier. There is a traffic light which means traffic is slow half of the times. When I was there in early September 2015, maintenance was going on beside the road, making it easier using the right lane for hitchhiking. There also is a Tim Hortons right across the street.
It might not be the best place to pull over, but we just had to wait for 5 minutes!
for going eastbound. close to info center, washrooms, maps, etc. people often take rest-stops here, good place to ask around for a ride as a second option
Hitched a ride to Lindsay at the intersection here, where people get off the high way. Ling light for people to stop at and safe place to stand. I waited about 5 minutes before I got a ride!
Great spot for heading towards Toronto
I started my cross-Canada hitchhike out of this spot.  As soon as I stood out on the road with my thumb I got a ride.

The dot is misplaced, sorry for my mistake. It should be on the bridge of the Boulevard Taschereau. Best place to go toward Qc city. Good visibility and place to stop. A lot of cars. Did it dozens of time, average waiting time around 15 min to get a lift far enough to get home. I suggest refusing lift from someone who offers to get you to the A-20 only, as it is so easy to find a lift for further.
Walmart parking lot. There's tones of RVs spending nights here, so you can try asking. Also - a good place to pitch up a tent - after all it's your RV :)
Got a ride to Edmonton within 15 minutes!
Hitching towards Edmonton. After the traffic lights cars are slow, drivers can see you and there's some place to pull over.
Waited 20 minutes and got a ride to Owen Sound. Very busy highway.
The end of the freeway, great place to hitch north to Guelph, just hard to get to. I walked 2 hours from the centre of Hamilton...

Not a hitching spot, but a great place to have a hike (around 2-3 hours, and beautiful).

As you walk down the tall metal stairs and keep heading south and south, finding your way through all of the paths, stick to the river banks, walk around the whirlpool, mind snakes on the way, then on the last stretch the path disappears, but if you keep walking south parallel to the river bank, making your way safe through the forest, you will shortly (maybe half a km after the end of the path, I don't rem

Hitching south-west towards Toronto.

Stood just before the no pedestrians/bicycles sign at the beginning of the highway. Police passed by a couple times and they didn't seem to mind.

A lot of traffic, good place to pull over just behind the sign. Got a ride to Toronto in 20 minutes.

Hitching west towards Toronto.

You can easily get here with a $3.5 bus from the centre of Ottawa. The spot after traffic lights, good place to pull over and cars are stopped/slow.

I was meaning to walk up to highway 7, but one of the first cars stopped and brought me west all the way to where the freeway ends, Carleton Place.
nice place to hitch this is the bus station so they have a parking to stop a lot of local people hitch there to go to maliotenam so use a sign thats the best to go further
nice place to the gas station to leave the town

73 South towards the bridge; trafic is good and the shoulder is large enough. But as there are many directions possible (20 East towards Rimouski, 20 West towards Montreal and 73 South towards St-Georges), it's better to have a sign.

The spot is easily accessible via the 400 bus line in summer, or the 25 year-round.

73 South towards the bridge; trafic is good and the shoulder is large enough. But as there are many directions possible (20 East towards Rimouski, 20 West towards Montreal and 73 South towards St-Georges), it's better to have a sign.

The spot is easily accessible via the 400 bus line in summer, or the 25 year-round.
As always, the ferry is the best place to find a ride. Just start talking to people and be nice.
As always the ferry is the best place to get a ride. Got mine with the first guys I asked. They were going as far as Happy Valley-Goose Bay, but I got out in Red Bay.

A good sleeping spot in the toilet near the western trailhead of Green Gardens :D. Didn't smell bad and you don't have to camp illegally. Just lock the door for a night :)


Also on the trail, you can easily hitch a ride.

A good sleeping spot in the toilet near the trailhead of Gros Mourne Mountain Trail :D. Doesn't smell bad and you don't have to illegally camp. Just lock the door for a night.


Also on the trail (which is beautiful, but strenuous) you can easily hitch a ride.

The ferry is the best place to get a ride, people are so nice, just start asking them.

To get on the ferry you need to pay $43.43 (as of June 2014). There's no way toget around this.
And one more time after 20 minutes got a ride almost to Quebec City.
Awesome spot

Best place to get to Quebec city. I would even suggest to ge a bit further, where you have this big green sign announcing your entrance into the park. If it's not the first, then the second car will stop to take you to Quebec city right away!
Gas station. The best possible hitch place in the area to go to Quebec city. All traffic going south of there is going towards Quebec city, very little local traffic.
First truck that drove by gave me a ride back to Sooke after hiking the Juan de Fuca.
Very easy getting picked up when heading east out of Port Renfrew.
The road is straight and the shoulders are wide past the intersection.  Lots of room for drivers to see you and pull over.

Direction: center of Montreal. I ended up near here going from Quebec City, thought I would have to take a bus to Montreal, but then noticed this spot, started hitching and got a ride after a short while. Worth trying!
After 15 minutes got a ride to Cape Split. Easy to get to the spot with buses.

If traveling to Wolfville or further North, where the highways from Halifax and Dartmouth converge make a perfect place to stand.  There is a very clearly marked sign just beyond which marks where pedestrians may not pass. So long as you are before this sign, you won't have a problem with police.  I have never waited more than 10 minutes at this location during the day.
Befriend some people on the trail and leave with them :D It's so beautiful, that people should be in a good mood.
Got tens of rides in local Quebec. Just get out of towns, they're small enough to walk and hitch. It works great and smoothly!
We stayed there only 12 minutes. It was very cold and cars drive quite fast here so we thought it'd be tough. Be we've been lucky. Nice guy drove us straight to Quebec
Gas station. Good traffic for the area, the path leads almost straight to Quebec city. Little local traffic
There's a stop sign just after leaving immigration which is a good place to catch rides through to Montreal.
Hitch up and down the 4 between Tofino and Uclulet to get to the beaches and board walks! Got picked up very easily, did all the boardwalks in one day!

Perfect place for hitching to Fairmont Hot Springs and further to Calgary. Has a huge pullout, plenty of opportunity for wild camping and space for cars to slow down. Heck one guy pulled over from the opposite lane of traffic to see if I wanted to go to Vancouver!
Your best chance from Val d'Or to get to Amos!

Hitchhiked there many times to get to Ottawa/Gatineau. A lot of people do the run between Abitibi an Gatineau so you should be able to find a lift pretty easily. Enough place for car to stop. And they have to slow down anyway to take the turn. So good sport overall
Got a ride to Ontario pretty much straight away

Take the train to Île Perrot OR take bus 211 from Lionel-Groulx subway station and walk from the terminus over the bridge to here. The highway becomes a boulevard for a short disance, there is heavy traffic but a lot of space to pull over, so it's very safe. Get a ride past Vaudreuil at least to be completely out of the metropolitain area.
Right after the lights, plenty of space, good visibility, low speeds.

This Irving Big Stop is a good place to catch long-distance traffic to or from Cape Breton, and is especially useful if you're coming from the ferry from PEI.  With a sign that said "Newfoundland", I got a ride all the way to North Sydney in less than half an hour.
Good for direction Port Alberni, Naniamo, you'll get traffic from both Tofino and Uclulet. Also easy to get a ride from here to both places.

This is very close to Canada's Wonderland. At the gates to the park they throw out insane amounts of food from anyone trying to enter the park gates with their own food. Shameful practice, but possibly a goldmine for dumpster diving? Anyone know? Leave a comment. I will check it out myself in August.

To my opinion, the best way to get there - operating year round, cheap, frequent: take the ttc bus 165D from Wilson subway to its last stop, Hwy 400 Car Pool Lot. Buses run Mon-Sat from 5.43am - 24 to 30 mins interval, last bus at 9.51pm. If You will not get a ride north, the last bus 165D back to Toronto runs at 10.54pm. Sunday: they run from 8.50am till 8.10pm - every 32-40 minutes. You can use a free transfer from the subway, and You are supposed to pay extra $0.35 since You travel past the c
Best spot to catch students leaving University in direction West - North or North-East
Best Relay point for direction Montreal, Service Station and Restaurant

NOTE: This whole on-ramp is currently on Redesign toward MTL - Relay point along the highway, 24h Services located at this exit (crossroad with Route 138) and possibility to hitch the on-ramp to Quebec
Local Traffic to St-Raymond
Decent spot to hitch to Quebec city
One of the Best Services to catch a ride, high frequentation with possibilities to go every direction: http://en.hitchwiki.org/?title=Point-du-Jour_Services
From Downtown: Take McNabb bus number 5 to the end of the line.  Walk east till just after the lanes merge into one and stand there.
A little walk from town but more than worth it if you are heading West. Lots of place for the cars to stop and a street light so they see you really well.

Le Restaurant du Pecheur: a regular stop, a very large parking entrance. Even if placed on the top of the hill, you can easily be seen if you are in the middle of the parking's length. Many long distancers stop there for lunch. Never waited more than 20 minutes there.
Hudson Inn - once you've reached that one, you almost always get a ride to Ottawa. It's a truck stop but there's just a lot of cars stopping there too.
All the Islands are VERY hitchikable, and this spot is one of too many to list :)

Going west from Toronto.
There's a nice straigth place to stop on the ramp to 400 highway.
To get there: get bus to brampton, hitch to Orangeville and from there to this point.

The friendly nature of Atlantic Canadians (as opposed to Western Canadians or Torontonians for example) is clear when you hitchhike in Nova Scotia.  I have never waited more than 20 minutes for a drive, so long as you are on a common, well traveled route during the day.
Eastward along Route 202, Very easy crossroad, shade, friendly ppl and good traffic flow
Anyone will give you a ride on Salt Spring. We got one within about 5 minutes, and they ended up taking us swimming at a beautiful beach on the way to Ganges! That's just the kind of place it is :)
Great spot for starting east towards Ottawa
Flying J truck stop. If you're heading toward west, this is a good place to go. I've drop a friend there and he found a ride to Toronto in 5min, dinner included.
A-70 East towards La Baie. As much traffic as the area can muster, enough room for folks to park.
went to Les promenades Gatineau
easy to go to gatineau
Good spot, going south. July 2025.
Walking out to the highway with my thumb out, good room for cars to pull over. Got a ride out to the highway. July 2025.
Good spot. Gas station right across the road, got a ride to Red bay from here. July 2025.
Great spot for hitching out of Stephenville. Got a ride all the way to Deer Lake in under five seconds. June 2025.

Going North, decent spot you can hitch the on ramp and the highway at the same time depending on the traffic. lots of stores nearby and what not. If you can try to get a ride before or on the ferry because they let the foot passengers off last so you can't really catch any of the traffic off the ferry since they've all left by the time you get off the boat. June 2025.
Good spot, lots of room for cars to pull over and also its a straight stretch so they can see you from far away. July 2025. Close to a town to.
Good Spot lots of room for cars to pull over got picked up quickly, heading to do the Gros Morne hike (you must do the hike if your in the area and fit, it has great scenery). July 2025.
Started a conversation with an older chap, ended up paying a taxi ride back to Rocky Harbour for me. July 2025.
Going west. Good traffic nothing crazy, long straight stretch, decent shoulder. If your going to be in this area you should go check out the Insectarium (cost's money). July 2025.
Great spot. Got a gas station and tims close by also its a long straight stretch. July 2025

Great spot. You got a gas station and tims in view so people stopping there can get a good look at you and have more time to decide whether to pick you up also good if need some food or water. Got a ride from here early in the morning all the way to St, John's. July 2025.

great spot with loads of space to stop direction east. Slow traffic coming from roundabout. Little sign gives you some shade too. Nice view. Treat yourself to a milkshake across the street. 10/10 would hitch again here.

pretty great spot, people turning are going slow and see you very well. Also, space to stop. We were standing in the scorching heat for only 5min, thank god. Just is a small hike from Lillooet, might be worth it. This place is hot in summer, bring enough water and sunscreen!

Busy yet remote gas station, trucks can stop here too. Got picked up after 20min after asking around. As of 09/25, Flix Buses stop here of the way to Medicine Hat and Edmonton, if you run out of luck.
Wide shoulders. A lot of traffic.
Heading west out of Pemberton, this spot is pretty solid.

This is a pretty good spot. There isn't a ton of room for vehicles to pull off safely, but there is enough. If you're heading west from Princeton this is where you want to post up. The folks at the husky across the road are pretty friendly.
Fairly quick after the first driver drop me off m, the second driver just approached shortly after
A random traffic light in the suburban sprawl, with a sign saying Canmore /shrug/

First hitchhike in Quebec for me !

After the last big intersection of Talbot Boulevard in Chicoutimi, direction Quebec / Mtl.
Practical for the possibility of sheltering from the rain at the SAQ Sélection.

I was trying to get to Kelowna, so I posted up before the Y. There's a huge shoulder, and traffic is moving pretty slow.

We took Hwy 33, We had a great conversation.
There's a bus that come's out here from Vernon. I posted up just past this little truck stop. Traffic is still moving pretty slow, I've had good luck here over the years.
Right after the light is the best spot heading south. The traffic is moving slow and there is a huge amount of room for folks to pull off.
If you're going down 3A towards Keremeos, Then this'll be your best bet. Don't try to walk it. There are way too many blind corners, and hardly any good pullouts along this highway.

When ever I'm going west from Keremeos, I usually post up across from the Canco. The last time I was there I didn't even make it out that far before someone stopped and picked me up. They gave me a ride all the way out to Tsawwassen.
Ramp on to trading post. Cars not going to fast. Not too much traffic but got a ride in 30 mins. After dropping me off he invited me to his house in Montreal and said he'd lend me one of his cars!

Awesome spot for going north out of Hope. Decent visibility, room to pull over and only traffic here is headed that direction. Not a long walk from town/campsites if you can't get a ride. Had 2 people stop in 20 mins, 2nd one took me all the way to North Bend.
Awesome spot for going east. Great visibility. Right after a traffic light, lots of room to pull over. Lots of through-traffic. Highly recommend.
You can easily go down the city from this parking lot exit.
You can easily go to Squamish or Whistler from here. We waited a bit because a lot of cars were full but all hikers here are very friendly.
Really great gas station with friendly staff. A good place to get a ride to the lake

There is not even a sign prohibiting to go on the on-ramp here! So it is technically legal contrary to all other on-ramps in the area!

Flat surface with enough land for cars to pull off. A nearby field close-by to nap, hide of stash things + close to a Walmart. This is straight a few minutes from the Vaughan station, the northmost station to leave the city. Easiest so far!
I caught a lift to St. Catharines from here.
J'ai marché jusqu'à la station Shell, et là France et son époux ont accepté de m'emmener jusqu'en Ontario.

Fait du pouce du village de St Tim jusqu'à la rive nord du St Laurent, à Saint Zotiquie, direction l'Ontario. Got there in a coupe of rides 

Incroyable, géniales expériences.
Got a ride to the bretelle d'autoroute of Chateauguay after failing to visit ces messieurs et dames de la réserve Mohawk -.-
Didn’t wait long and got the coolest ride ever. All the way to the coast!
Not the best wait time but the best driver ever picked me up here. Took me way further than he was intending just to get me further down the road.
First car I stuck my thumb out for pulled over and took me out of the way of where they were going to take me to my uncles in Stanley. Smoothest hitching experience ever.
Good spot for going West. Waited just 15 min. Cars can spot you early and slow down because of the traffic lights
Great spot to go to the east, especially for truck. Go there in the morning if you want to go far away.

There is a park and ride, just past the end of the on ramp. If you're hitching in the winter don't accept a ride to the ski hill unless you're going up there. In the past, I did and I spent the night in the middle of nowhere.
We were waiting at the red light to ask driver.
Just stay on the ferry and ask people, the second car I asked picked me up and got me to Vernon
Lots of people traveling long distances
Cyprus Lake road is forbidden to pedestrians, but park rangers encouraged me to hitchike and the third car picked me up (first two wanted to but we're full of camping gear)
2 cars stopped in 3 minutes, people here are super nice
Getting a ride on all of the Islands are super-easy. There are even official Hitch-hiking stops along the roads.
I was standing at the end of the ramp. Basically just off the highway. I got really lucky. It was after 6pm on a Friday. The guy could've taken me all the way to Kamloops.
Great place to get west out of Banff. Walkable from the downtown. Don't go to the gas stations in Banff, as they are too far from the highway and only local people use them.

Amazing place to hitch, unfortunately I got a ride with a creepy American guy who lied about where he was going so after a few miles, I got off the car and decided to hitch back to this place, then got a ride all the way to Golden
STAY ON THE RAMPE IN WINTER, the shoulder is really small all the way no one (or almost) will stop on the HW
très bon spot pour aller vers le lac Saint-Jean Je me suis mis devant le passage piéton où il y avait de la place pour qu'une voiture s'arrête

A-70 West towards JonquiÃ¨re, Lac-Saint-Jean. As much traffic as the area can provide, right after a stoplight. Lots of room for cars to park. You might hit local traffic, make sure you know where you go. If you want to go to the Lac-Saint-Jean area, avoid anybody whom drives less further than Saint-Bruno.

Waited at the off road before Pizza Hut with an Irish flag tied to my camping gear. After no more than 15 minutes a man pulled up in his company truck and offered to bring me some of the way. After chatting for a bit he told me he’d go about 10 minutes out of the way on his journey to bring me all the way to the entrance to tea lake campground. Lovely chap

Waited on the slip road by pizza hut. After 30 mins got a ride from a lovely dude who then offered to give weed and booze supply runs for summer camp. Let me drink beer in passenger seat and offered his dab pen from the trunk!

Got exceptionally lucky here.
Lady saw me at the tims with my bags, thought I might be a hitchhiker and when leaving stopped for me. Had barely pulled out my sign.
There is a truck stop here and good visibility. I had the shortest wait of my life here, but I got lucky.
good spot for going east, waited about 20 minutes for a long ride
Not so much traffic, there's some place to pull-over. Stood for around 40 minutes just before the sign "no pedestrians" and got a nice ride for 2 hours east.

If you are coming from Quebec, take the Ferry to Levis and walk or hitch a ride to this place where you can easily catch people making longer distances. It's very hard to leave Quebec city by the bridges to the 20 otherwise.
good spot to hitch towards the east. Got a ride to Thunder Bay pretty quick early in the morning.
If you get dropped off in and around Kenora and plan on going further east this will probably be your best shot. There is a nice set of lights so people can see you and a shoulder to pull over.
great spot from the campsite. Much space, great view. We were two and got a ride to Banff pretty quick.

If you are staying at the campsite and want to go south towards Banff this is the best stop. Stand right where the shoulder reaches it maximum width so that cars coming from Jasper and the campground have a good visual on you and enough room to stop behind. I hitchhiked together with another guy and it took about an hour until someone stopped. If you are going by yourself it'll be even easier to get a ride.
Good traffic. Lots of room for cars to safely stop. Got a ride to Banff.
This is your best bet for hitching west from Calgary.
Got a direct ride to Banff on friday around 5pm, shoulder is not really wide but people could pick you up !

Waited between Mcdonalds and the gas station for 5min, cars are able to stop before going into the road. Great spot to be seen! I recommend. We headed Quebec City in 2hours from there, the driver took us where we needed in the city.

We were heading to Quebec city from montreal, got here it started to get dark and we've been very lucky after few minutes someone took us straight to Quebec, gave us a tour of the old town and drop us right at the door of our friend

Ultramar station

Towards Montréal or Trois-rivières/Québec.

Lot of drivers, ask'em !

We stand a few steps before the pedestrians and bicycle sign, so that cars have enough time to stop after us, before going to the high road. We stand for 40min with a sign for Quebec and then someone took us to Berthierville where we waited 5minutes before having a lift to Quebec City.
I hitchhiked here just today and got ride within couple minutes. Very good spot, I was standing more down the road, by the no pedestrian and bicycles sign.

Excellent moyen de sortir de MontrÃ©al vers l'est.  Prendre l'autobus pour Repentigny (dÃ©part mÃ©tro Radisson) et dÃ©barquer a la gare d'Ã©change.  Une lÃ©gÃ¨re marche sur la rue de la Fayette et vous Ãªtes sur une entrÃ©e d'autoroute trÃ¨s passante ou il y a mÃªme une lumiere de circulation.  80% des gens passant a cette endroit empruntent l'autoroute.
I got a ride pretty quickly. Buddy was crazy, but he got me farther down the road.
Seems ideal, but I waited all evening with no ride, spent the night in the forest, then walked up the road to the Hotsprings turn-off and waited 2 hours till a ride

Good spot if you are heading north. Space to stop, low speed, ...
Close to gasstation.
Yeah, if you're going to Kelowna this is your spot.

Good spot if you are going to Kellowna.
Lot's of space to pull over, right after lights. Close to information centre.

It's a great spot for cars to stop. Was just standing opposite of the police station and even though it took me a few hours, I got a lift all the way to Thunder Bay. There's also a decent spot to pitch a tent behind Tom Hortons
Enough space to pull over, it was pouring rain but even though there were two of us, we managed to get a ride in a few minutes
I guess i was lucky, waited 30 minutes for a direct ride to Sault Ste Marie, a trucker just stopped in the side road.
I think it was the second car that picked me up. Hitchhiking is generally viewed as a form of public transit in the area, and people are pretty friendly.
Hitching in the Kootenays is good. People are pretty relaxed. If you're hitching North to Nelson. The shoulders are wide through town and when you get to the end there is a nice tree to wait under.
The transcanada was closed between lake Louise and Golden, so there was a lot of traffic there. But in general it's a great place, there is a space for trucks to stop and speeds are quite low.
The second car stopped :D 2 minute wait maximum.

Hitching south to Radium Hot Springs and farther.

Good spot, drivers can see you and there's a big parking lot to pull over.

This spot is pretty fast. But the visibility is ok, and there is room to pull off the road.

There is a trail system that runs along the highway, follow it until you find the maintenance access. Dont jump or vandalize the fence. There is a gate, jump it or you can wade through the bramble... and you'll be on the highway. Hitching is fairly common in this area so you shouldn't have to wait too long.
first car that passed
Straight stretch, lots of room for drivers to pull over.  Easily accessible by taking the #257 bus to Horseshoe Bay.  Waited about 20 minutes
great spot for hitching a ride west got picked up by a trucker coming out of the truck stop
Wide shoulder to stop, people are going long distances, I got a ride to Regina almost instantly.
Really good. Easy to get close with $2 bus fare from the centre of Winnipeg. Waited 50 min with an "Alaska" sign and got a ride to the highway 1 and 16 split near Portage la Prairie.
Had a ride for Brandon in 30 minutes with a "Regina" sign
Great location, near a truck-stop. Wides shoulders, but speeds can be high when lights are green.

Two boys (one with dredlocks) = 5 hours of waiting without succcess.
After 5 hours we moved to the different spot and never waited more than 1,5h on the way to Kelowna.
But place looks like very good: lots of cars passing not so fast with lots of space to stop.
Not a bad spot but most drivers don't go further than Abbotsford
Good spot, but I had to wait a hour and half under the rain ...
Looked like a got spot, but actually took a long time to get picked!
Was an excellent spot for me, heading East, then North on Hwy 1.
Good spot, there is lots of traffic and plenty of space to stop. Traffic light slows it down. I got a direct ride to Tofino after about 10 minutes
look out 4/laugh at the "no hitchhiking pickup is illegal" sign
I tried to hitch after the traffic lights to get to Tofino, took a while, probably should have tried from the information center.
Traffic lights with a Information center. Substitute spot if you coming off the ferry and can't get a ride. Good for going north or to Tofino, Port Alberni.
good spot just as other reviews say
Definitely the best place to get out of North Bay, didn't even have to stick my thumb up and got a ride west
We (French couple) only waited 1 minute to get a ride to Sudbury

The best spot for going West out of North Bay.  There's a stop light and plenty of room to pull over.  If you go down the road to the hospital, there's another light but it only turns red when a car is turning in or out of the hospital and there's less room to pull over.  I hitched over a dozen times from this spot.  Unfortunately, North Bay is not a good hitching town and I averaged over an hour wait.
Plenty of space to pull over, but cars come at around 90kph. Got a ride in less then 5 mins with a sign to Québec City
Possibly a good spot to continue further to Montreal

Good spot overall.
Took a while, but it was getting into the evening. Found a long ride all the way into Saskatchewan.
Again 2 of us, we waited quite long, 45 minutes, but I guess it's just random. Good place to pull over, right after traffic lights, so people have loads of time to notice you. Direction east.
Good spot to pull over right after traffic lights. Direction east.

I posted up at the intersection of hwy-6 and 1st ave.

This spot should probably be moved, it's in the middle of the trees.

Get here early in the day to catch folks making a day trip to the Okanagan.

Traffic volume is really low, but the percentage of drivers that are willing to stop is pretty high. I ended up getting a ride all the way to Kelowna.
Very few cars, but they are slow and people are friendly. If you get a ride to the ferry then it's easy to get another one towards Vernon
Spot for going to Victoria, had a long wait tho...
Heavy traffic, very stoppable, good visibility, but speeds are high if cars're not stopped by the traffic light.
Little traffic due to industrial area, but most will be going a fair distance from here
didn't even have time to put my bag down after getting to the spot before getting a ride! we were 1f 1m though
Got a ride to Vancouver after an hour of thumbing.

Hitching west towards Vancouver. All the traffic going Trans Canada has to stop there at traffic lights, so it's a good spot. Also wide shoulders to pull over.

And there's a lot of gas stations and dining places around, you can go there and ask people.

beaucoup de trafic directement sur Charest, je m'étais installé sur la petite rue parallèle qui lui donne accès. Pas un bon endroit pour sortir de la ville vers l'autoroute 20. Finalement quand une personne m'a prise c'était pour me rapprocher des ponts, ce qui a été beaucoup plus facile par la suite.
Lot of traffic here but people already quite fast here. 3 lanes so many of them don't even look at you. Anyway we got a short ride to get further out of the city

Sign is very helpful here since new construction in Quebec city (winter 2011) created many new interchanges in the West of Quebec. There is a Tim Hortons there now and a Gas station. Bus shelter to give you cover if it is raining and drivers have TWO places to safely pull over for you. This road also directly feeds into the A20.
Nice spot

I went there going to Montreal looking at the first comment, i guess i got really unlucky because i took me 2 hours to get my first ride ... and it was really short. Took me 6 hours to get to Montreal. Unfortunately walking on the 417 in Ontario is forbidden, so no choice but waiting on the ramp !
Although cars come here with quite a bit of speed, there is a lot of space to safely pull over. This spot is probably better when there is little traffic. Got a direct ride to Montreal in 20 minutes.
got stuck for the day and night good spot nonetheless better than just outside of thunder bay
Nice lady at the store brought me a coffee because it was raining. Got a ride all the way to Winnipeg.
Truck stop is the saving grace here & makes life pretty easy.
Good spot if you are going west. Campsite right beside this spot.
Moderate place with place to pull over (beside gas station).
Relatively good spot. It's after lights, but only narrow shoulder to pull over.

Good spot if you are heading south. Many cars passing, but mainly tourists and "distatnt" people from Kelowna. It's right after a lights with lots of space to stop.
This spot is reachable by public transportation. If you are going from downtown go to the Westbank exchange by bus 97 and after it take bus 22 to the Beach (but be aware bus 22 isn't so much frequen).
Very good spot, if you are going to vancouver. It's right after lights and cars could stop here. Wait less than 5 min.
Try to hitchhike here with sign saying Vancouver was not a good idea. After about a hour I decided to go with my thumb only, got ride in 20 minutes to the southest point of Whistler.
After the last bus stop, this is the place to be.  Straight, good visability, and there's plenty of room to pull over.  Traffic driving here is usually bound for Pemberton at least.

Ein guter Startpunkt, um von Victoria zum Juan de Fuca Trail zu kommen. Downtown in den Bus 50 einsteigen. Am Langford Exchange in die Linie 61 wechseln (meist bleibt es der selbe Bus) und bis zur Haltestelle Grant Road W at West Coast Road fahren. Dank BC Transit kostet das alles nur 2,50$. Da die Ansagen im Bus schlecht zu verstehen sind, lohnt es sich, dem Busfahrer zu sagen, dass man da hin will. Er wird euch dann direkt an der Ecke aussteigrn lassen, wodurch ihr euch ein paar Meter Fußmarsc
There is a bus stop at this place, so it's quite easy for the drivers to stop to give you a lift. As it is very easy to hitchhike at Saltspring, it won't take you too long.

Standed their for 55 min , most of people will think u a homlesse or else even thoug i had a sign with quebec , people even eitheir open their window to give me money or close is thinking im gonna rob them lol anyway try to make eye contact with the driver showing them ur sign and even if u feel they fine talk to them , it did pay after almost an hour even thoug at the begining the driver see me but didnt make a move , he end up droping me at charlemagne where u git a ride under 1 min !

Not the best place to hitchike as no space for care to pull in properly , but it work as fine , as their is the right lane going right , took me 35 min for a bus of passenger to take me all the way to Toronto !
Nice spot , 50 min waiting time but a straight ride to regina !
Maybe bad luck as wass some rd work so waited almost 3h to get droped half an hour up as heading to Winnipeg
I had good luck here. The traffic light slows down traffic and the shoulders are wide.
Been droped off her from regina and only 30 min wait to go all the way to Winnipeg ! Not bad
Early morning 6:30 am , waited half an hour to get ride to cache greek as i wass heading to alaska but wass aiming for prince george for the day went even furthur up !
Amazing hitchhiking spot, got a ride all the way to Kelowna pretty much straight away

Going East, Walked from the border, picked up on my way to the HWAY (walked with my thumb on) and dropped  to the next town, Chilliwack.
Guy alone with a big backpack.
Brilliant spot, managed to get a ride all the way to Vancouver
There are a couple of gas stations around here where we solicited a ride without too much trouble.
Brilliant spot, the two of us managed to get a ride all the way to Thunder Bay
Direct ride for Thunder Bay on a thursday morning. The guy was actually going to Vancouver ... lucky shot !
forget about a bus, hitchhiking is easy in Quebec (if you speak French)

Truck stop. I spent the afternoon here. Most truck driver won't accept to pick you up due to Compagny policy, but you will find a free spirit one who will accept. I got a ride straight to Edmonton from here. Good option on a rainy day!
Cars come fast, but there is plenty of space to pull over. Good spot, but I had to wait quite a bite before being picked up.
I took the #257 Express + C12. Not the safest spot because it is at the end of curvy slope, but I got a ride in less than 10 mins. Good space to pull over.

If you don't ask people on the ferry because you fell asleep (like me), this is your best shot of getting a ride. This is where the trans canada begins again, the shuttle bus can take you fairly close. Try not to miss it though (like me), cause that will decrease your chances. If you miss all the cars coming off the ferry you'll have to wait til the next one comes. You can stand anywhere in the curve, the shoulder is very wide. Got a ride within 20 minutes.
This place seems to be really great but it took me more than 2 hours to hitch a ride as most cars head south
There is barely any shoulder there now plus a no pedestrian and no stopping/parking sign. If you want to hitch east go west to the next intersection.
Eastward location on the TransCanada

Probably the best spot for hitchhiking out of Thunder Bay. Traffic is slow cause of the lights with a gravel shoulder to pull over. You also get traffic from the 102 going east. One thing that needs to be noted is that there is a no pedestrian sign there. If you don't wish any anger with the cops I'd probably stand in front of it. Got a ride within 7 minutes taking me all the way to Marathon.

Fairly decent spot if you are heading down to Regina. There was a construction going on in early September 2015 so cars were going at slow speeds. Take the number 17 bus towards Stonebridge and get off at Hunter/Senick. There is a fence you have to climb over in order to reach the Highway but it's not too hard.
Got dropped off here and got a ride to Jasper within 5 minutes. Cars are going a bit slower as they are just leaving the city.

Waited for about 15 minutes until a guy stopped. He only went to the prairie exit but I still think this is a great spot for going west. I would go to the most western point of the intersection in order to catch as much traffic as possible.
Got a ride from here to Jasper in 10 minutes. Lots of slow-moving traffic coming in from the Anthony Henday.
Got picked up to Edmonton within 10 minutes of waiting.
Towards Calgary. Waited here in the rain and got picked up within 10 minutes.

I had to wait a short while but there are tonnes of workers who use this road to get to the mines.  They tend to be of the laid back sort.  My ukulele broke at this spot. I put it underneath a green sign that said "Thunderbay 300km." If you find this ukulele please let me know!
good anytime other than dead of winter in a storm. hah.

There aren't a ton of cars, but definitely enough, and a good enough place to stop. Make sure you stand far back enough so that cars coming out of Moncton will see you and maybe stop as well. Got a ride going all the way to Montreal after about half an hour.
Good for going West. Possibly East though too. Check out the Big Stop to the west if you want a ride East.
In 20 minutes I had two cars stop - one going to Cape Breton (wrong way for me) and the next one all the way to Moncton.

Pretty good spot if you were on your way from Halifax to New Brunswick etc. or towards Cape Breton, and the driver was not going the same way. The intersection itself, between highways 102 and 104, is very busy and cars are going quite fast, so it might be better to stay here. There's a traffic circle in the junction, so cars are going fairly slow, and there's a good place to stop. There's also a gas station with toilets and a convenience store, and a Tim Horton's for free wifi.
I think the spot is in the wrong place... There's a circle-K 2-3km south, where road 2 meets road 102, maybe that's the one?
If your driver is going another way, try to get dropped in the Big Stop around here, and go ask the truckers and car-drivers!

Hitching to the Eastern Shore. Take bus 61, 68 or 401 to get here, and get off the farthest you can on road 7. If you walk a bit next to the road you're sure to find a place where cars can stop easily.
Got a ride to Radium easily, than had to wait quite a while to get to Golden (not so much traffic).
Hitching out of Invermere north towards Golden/Banff. Long stretch of a road and a wide shoulder easy to pull over.
Got picked up here almost the moment I stepped on the highway.  I would consider myself fairly lucky, it's generally harder than that, according to a few people I talked to
Acceptable spot if going east.  Flat and straight, people can see you from a distance, and there is plenty of room on the shoulder to safely pull over.

Started at 7 am in mid September, maybe that's why had to wait quite a bit. First a couple going just 10 km or so stopped, I didn't go, then after hour and a half I got a ride to Banff (with tourist stopping in all nice places - awesome!).

Hitching south to Lake Louise, Banff. The icefields parkway is amazing and so much worth going.

The spot just after traffic lights, so cars are stopped and can see you for a while when waiting. Pull over lane is quite short, but it's possible.
After an hour got a short local ride, then had to wait 3 hours to get to Haines Junction...

Hitching to Alaska.

Cars slow after traffic lights, drivers can see you and good place to pull over. Easy to get a short local ride, but going farther is tricky, as it's hard to get picked up by tourists here. Your better shot would be asking at gas stations.
Quite easy to hitch up to Fort St. John, then it gets tricky. A lot of locals here, later just tourist RVs.
Got a ride to Hinton after 30 minutes.

Hitching west towards Jasper, Grand Prairie (or Alaska :D ).

Probably as good as anyway on this highway. Cars go really fast, but they can see you, there's a lot of traffic and decent place to pull over.

Got dropped off here by friends. Going to Edmonton, after 15 minutes I had a ride for 10 km, then after 15 minutes a ride to Lloydminster, and from there after 15 minutes a ride to Edmonton. Seems these parts of the world are really friendly :)
Dropped by my host in Saskatoon, going to Edmonton took me 15 minutes  to have a ride for Lloydminster on wednesday around 1pm

The spot looks really good hitching wise, but I would probably recommend waiting here until you get a really long ride, since in other places on the highway cars go much faster. After 15 minutes I took a short ride for a few miles, and then hitching the Yellowhead turned into a nightmare. Don't know why, but "Friendly Manitoba" was really unfriendly. There's not a lot of cars farther on.

Hitching towards Saskatoon, Edmonton.

There's a good space to pull over and cars go slow since they have just turned and the traffic lights slow them down. Not so much traffic though.

The spot seems perfect and probably relatively is. I waited quite a bit though with a sign to Alaska :) After 1,5 h a great guy going to Calgary stopped (actually drove back to get me after passing me and then reconsidering) and brought me in 2 days to Winnipeg.

Heading north-west towards Thunder Bay, Winnipeg and farther on.

Probably the best it gets. Out of the city, so who goes, goes far. You probably can start closer to the city centre, I started here as I got dropped off close by.

Long straight stretch for cars to see you, a lot of place to pull over.
Waited 40 minutes and got a ride to Hamilton.

Hitching west towards Hamilton, then possibly Toronto.

Some place to pull over, some traffic, sooner or later something will stop.
Waited 40 minutes and got a ride to Grimsby just before St. Catharines.

Hitching south-east towards Hamilton, St. Catharines, Niagara Falls.

Stood just before no pedestrians/bicycles sign. Great space to pull over, decent traffic.
Waited 50 minutes on a weekday morning and got a ride to Burlington

Hitching south-west towards Burlington, Hamilton, Niagara Falls.

Easy to get there with Toronto/Mississauga public transit, but costs $7 for two transit fares, which is not so great...

Stood just before no pedestrians/bicycles sign. Decent traffic, slow after lights, little place to pull over, but possible.
Direction Tadoussac, cars goes slowly but they don't have a lot of space to stop
One of the few places in Montreal, easily accessible via bus (179 from L'Acadie Station), where you'll find a freeway entrance with a large shoulder. Good trafic, but often not going that far.

Direction west: Forestville, Tadoussac, Quebec City.

There's an extra lane to pull-over, decent traffic and drivers can see you as they are going. Chances are you get a short ride though.
You may try getting a ride on the tour of the power plant, which takes place a couple times every day. Worked for me.
Quite easy to get a ride of a few km - to the junction where all the people turn to the Muskrat Falls dam building camp. A lot of traffic there. But after it gets very empty.
Direction Gros Mourne and north. The spot has everything - reasonable traffic, place to pull over, cars not so fast. Got my ride here at 9 pm when it was almost dark.
Got a fast ride from Cape Spear to St. John's.
Pretty easy to get a ride back from Cape Spear to St John's by hitching at the parking lot exit, though I don't imagine anybody is going much further.

I'm proud of my discovery. Found it with Google StreetView as a stretch of the road with some decent place to pull over. Then went there and it was actually good. Loads of traffic, waited less than 30 minutes.

You get there with the bus 6 from Downtown (as of June 2014), need to walk a small distance from the bus stop to the road through the Bowring Park.
Waited before the gas station. Got a ride within half an hour.
Gas Station. Good for getting out of St. John's

Got a ride to Saint John's on the ferry. People really kind, mostly older couples, every second person wanted to pick me up, but they were all going to Deer Lake, Corner Brooke or somewhere else. So I kept asking and found a guy going all the way to Saint John's.
The best spot to hitch from or to Newfoundland is in the boat itself. Ask the people, it's worth it!

Got a ride to Saint John's on the ferry. People really kind, mostly older couples, every second person wanted to pick me up, but they were all going to Deer Lake, Corner Brooke or somewhere else. So I kept asking and found a guy going all the way to Saint John's.

There does not seem to be any getting around the (currently $40.70) per passenger fare for the ferry to Port Aux Basques, Newfoundland.  There is sometimes a ferry direct to Argentia (much closer to St John's than Port Aux Basques) but it is much more expensive.

I found the North Sydney ferry terminal and ferry itself to be surprisingly difficult places to hitch for an onward ride to St John's but they are still probably your best shot.  People may be reluctant to commit to taking you for the w
Direction east. Good place to pull over, waited shortly, got a short ride.
Direction east. Stand before the sign forbidding pedestrians to go farther. There's place to pull over, good traffic. I got a ride quickly, was just a short one though.
It was a long walk from Kamloops, but once there I didn't have to much trouble. the traffic was a little light.
Montreal or Cornwall. Easy place, have fun!
There is a nice wide pull out for traffic to stop here. Also traffic will be coming in slow off the overpass.
There is a nice little pull out for east bound travelers about 500m past the Hwy 1 and Hwy 23(North) intersection. Its an up hill walk.
I was going down the Crowsnest and my driver was going up the coquihalla. He dropped me off here and I got picked up right away.

There is a good spot here for cars to pull off, and a store near by. There will be a lot of local traffic turning of at the next intersection, so do get discouraged if you don't get picked up right away.
The shoulders are wide enough for cars to stop, there is a gas station near by.
There are stores, a place for cars to pull off, and kelowna city transit comes all the way down here.
Most local traffic heads up to the mine. I got dropped off here latter in the day but I was still lucky. Hwy 3's a good hwy.
From Ft Macleod, North. Get here early, a lot of traffic will be heading into Calgary for work.
There is a gas station here, access to city transit, and it's safe and pretty visible. The hwy is a little quieter then the trans-Can but people are more likely to stop.
Decent spot if going south.  Speeds fairly low, and there is room for people to pull over safely.

It's illegal, but have never had problems - I think that goes only for rural areas of highways. And there's so much traffic, that it's hard not to picked up right away. Just find a safe place for cars to stop and be cautious.
Direction Montreal. Pretty empty, but got a local ride quickly. And had luck to be driven to the spot out of Quebec.
Direction Charlottetown. In the fall very empty road, but still quite quickly got a ride. I guess in the summer gets crowded with tourists.
Direction north. Fairly busy traffic, friendly people. Just find a good spot for cars to stop, smile and you got it :)
Well, we got lucky and after a couple of minutes found a ride straight to Quebec City, haha!
There's a gas station over here, so you can ask people. We got lucky, so I'm not sure about traffic (though it didn't seem very busy). Direction east.

Good spot for going to the Kootenay Lake ferry, Kaslo, or the long way around to the Slocan.  Situate yourself at the EMS station.  Plenty of room to pull over.  People driving slow after a stop light.  Friendly folks in Nelson.  Should get a ride within 30 mins at a reasonable time of day.

Going to Ottawa, got a ride in 5 minutes :)
Guy alone w/ big backpack

If you want to get out of Halifax, take the Airport bus out of town. It only costs 3.25 and takes a half hour to get out there.  from the bus stop you can walk down bell boulevard to the on ramp and a lot of people heading toward Truro will pass you.  I got picked up by 3 guys on their way to Toronto.

Found it nearly impossible to hitch anywhere closer to the city, and here you are more likely to find cars that are leaving the island. We waited outside a gas station at the intersection, about 15-20 minutes. 

C'était impossible pour trouver un ride plus proche à la ville-- ici, il y a plusieurs voitures qui vont sortir l'isle de Montréal. Nous avons attendus à une station d'essence, au feu tricolore, pour 15-20 minutes.
A fair bit of long-distance traffic stops at this Petro-Canada.
Much easier to get a ride here (past the end of the autoroute, so hitching on the road is legal) than at the onramps and truck stop further east.
Hitched a ride to Tofino from under the over pass. steady light traffic with good visibility but long wait.
very slow, good visibility, steadily light traffic.
Going East on a friday around 11a, got picked up pretty fast, all the way to Ottawa. Wide shoulder and straight line. Guy alone with a big backpack

Going East on a weekday afternoon waited 1h maybe. I got lucky and got a direct ride for Thunder Bay (the guys was going further, to Timmins). Cars are going fast but it's straight and clear, with a shoulder wide enough.
Guy alone with a big backpack.

Going East, you can access here easily taking a local bus (n° 19, 2 or 3$) and walk a bit. There is not that much from this point, you're out of the short local traffic. Got picked up pretty easily, but not for a long ride.
Guy alone with big backpack, around 2pm on a weekday.
Going East, easy to find a direct ride to Canmore or Calgary walking on the HWY, but in summer time only. With the snow the shoulder is really narrow, stay on the ramp is probably better.
Got a ride here reasonably fast going East. This spot is in full view of oncoming traffic from both the highway and the exit.

To go to St Anne des Monts (and Tadoussac).
2 minutes walking from bus 800 stop 'La Cimenterie'. 
Traffic is not very important, but cars arrive slowly in this on-ramp, and they can stop easily.
Near longueil metro station, just before a ramp to highway, cars can easily stop. Cars are coming from Longueil, and from boulevard La Fayette.
Illegal as it his on the highway, but still a great spot to live the city.

I stayed at the hostel just down the highway, and a local recommended this spot to me. This spot is suited for going west because its past the squilax turnoff, and there is a nice pullout on the road here. If you are heading east, go on the opposite side of the turnoff, as a lot of local traffic flows through there.
Coming from Regina and going to Saskatoon, i've been dropped here. Waited 20 minutes for a direct ride to Saskatoon on a friday around 5pm.
Coming from Regina and going to Saskatoon, i took a bus (2.50$) to get to the Walmart and then walked directly on the Highway. Immediately picked up, the guy dropped me in Lumsden.
There is a big side road for cars to stop here ! I walked here from the wallmart (long lake RD - 80) and got picked up !
A good crossing i think, enlightened at night. Got a direct ride for Sudbury in 1h.
Got a ride for Deep River in 20 minutes with a military.
Taken by militaries going to their base in (near from deep river) 20 minutes
On the ramp going West, direct ride in 20 minutes on friday afternoon for Ottawa.
The best place to hitch up-island from. It's right at the end of Langford, just before the Malahat starts, and it's right where a big turn in for the ice cream shop is.
The off-ramps for either direction are probably your best bet when trying to hitchhike through Medicine Hat. I have seen a few folks waiting here but I sure wouldn't
Heavy traffic, but enough space to stop.
Stand here with a sign "T.C.H." It's good start if you want to reach the highway.
Small town nice people

Destination: Toronto. Not the best shoulder for hitching, but most traffic on this road should be getting on the highway, so there's no need to walk all the way to the onramp. Traffic stops at the nearby traffic light, so drivers have plenty of time to see you.
In New Denver, the best spot to wait is right in the center of town at the main cross-roads.
Right before the bridge on both sides of the road there is plenty of room for cars to pull over. Going east, you are in full view of the intersection up the road, making for swift waiting times.

Good spot if you want to go in Toronto or in the direction of Detroit.
I waited 10 minutes. And if it's raining there is a bridge under which you can take shelter.
Taking the 73 south to Beauceville.. good spot, plenty of space, and slow traffic heading to Pont P. Laporte. Waited 5 minutes
Pretty good spot. Near a chicken restaurant called Scores, gas station nearby as well. We (1 guy, 1 girl) stood on the on ramp with sign "Quebec". Took 20 min.

Whitbourne Junctions. There are a couple gas stations here. The highway to the left next to Mill pond goes south to the Argentia Ferry to Nova Scotia. So if headed to Southern shore this is a good spot to request. Most Newfoundlanders know this spot.
Gas stops & coffee along this stretch. Gander is a common stopping place across Newfoundland.

Good Spot. There is a mall, restaurants, gas stations and hotels on this part of Confederation Drive. Good for heading South/West. Get on the Highway itself too if you like to catch all traffic heading Southwest that is passing Corner Brook.

All over Atlantic Canada, Irving/Circle-K Big Stop truck stops are great places to hitch, as they are frequented by drivers going a long way.  Amenities typically include public showers, free wifi, and a covered area outside the door where you can stand with a sign while staying out of the rain.  Staff never bothered me even if I had not bought anything.

At this particular Irving I waited over an hour but then got a ride all the way to Charlottetown, PEI (my destination).

It was getting dark and I was about to head into the forest to pitch my tent after 1 hour of waiting, but then... an old hippie stopped for me and took me all the way to Clearwater. He let me stay in his house for a night, I got something to eat, a warm coffee in the morning, two hands full of weed and a 20 dollar bill!!! My best hitchhiking experience so far.
Just get yourself a rest, sit down and wait with a sign. Somebody will take you, nice landscape. Just dream and go by the flow!
Much traffic going east. Good spot, drivers can pull over. Waiting time about 30 min. They take you and they take you a long time ;-) Canada rocks!
Direction West (Portneuf County) or possibly South (Levis - Charny area across the bridges) just a the beginning of the highway, a sign would be require, there is also Gas Stations to ask
(South) Few Gas Station to ask in the village itself, otherwise you have to make sure that you get a ride directly to St-Augustin, Quebec or the highway on-ramp
The best spot to reach to not be stuck in Trois-Rivieres, possibility to try to catch the highway traffic as well. Do not stop anywhere before Portneuf County beyond this point
24h Services located here
There is a Petro-Canada Gas Station at the exit of Dorval Terminal where many cars stops before leaving Montreal
Along the road, on top of the hill it is the remaining point before the speed limit top-up, direction South
Just before the cemetary, direction North to St-Leonard
Direction North, the best is to hitch by the local shop directly in the centre of the village
Direction South, cars have to slow down to deal with the curve, there is a kerb to pull aside as well
It's best to still do it in the industrial area before the road curves (direction Westward)
Towards Bathurst, good ramp. Ask to be dropped there if you arrive from Quebec with driver that continues in GaspÃ©sie.
Heading East, good spot at the Petro Canada there, day or night it was fine
Heading West, usually you can get a ride to RiviÃ¨re du Loup. There is quita a lot of traffic, so hitchiking right after the street light might be a good idea. Same opposite, heading East
Safe and nice spot, even at night.
Might be long (and if low traffic, might be worth walking to the highway, but illegal. It's best to give it a try here first. Usually not too long.
Service station, very common stop for trucker, might be the best place to stop if you have to change rides because you/your driver is going to route 132/185.
Last Stop going East before the bridges. Most of the people coming from Montreal go to Quebec city, therefore you best ask to be dropped here if you are heading East South of the St-Lawrence River.
From/To Granby
Heading East, a bit further, but during business hours it might be more easy than the one on Marie-Victorin. It's in an industrial park.
going north
Here is your only hope of getting out of Hope. At least, if you're heading to Vancouver.
The shoulder is massive here! It's as if the road has it's own hitchhiking lane! :)

For heading west on the Trans-Canada. Stand 15 meters before the entrance to the motel. Wide shoulders, and people drive slowly through the town and towards the curve. Has very bad reputation, yet I got a ride there in 15 minutes, all the way to Sault St Marie. Started hitchhiking 15:00, with a big sign.

To hitchhike westward from Canmore. Get down to the point where the intersection connects to the Trans-Canada (road no. 1), there you'll find a short strech where cars can pull off. Your best bet is in the morning, when all the people who are going to work in the west (maiely Banff) leave Canmore through this exit. Might only get you as far as Banff, but at least you'll be past the entrance, and riding with someone who works inside will rid you from paying entrance fee.

To hitchhike to Toronto, get the train at Veldome/Lucien-L'Allier (where the Metro meets the train, you can use any other station on that line) and head to Dorion. Once there get to the 20 highway that passes south of the rail through the town, to the last set of traffic light. Wide shoulders, slow and freaquent traffic, only problen is that big vehicles are forbiden from stopping. Took me 30 minutes with a sign, as from 11:30 am.

Going south, we got a ride in less than an hour. Keep in mind, though, that this road is seldomly used with very little traffic. There are no real settlements between Hopewell and the coast, so if you do get a ride past Hopewell, you're probably getting a ride for a reasonably long distance.

Prendre le mÃ©tro jusqu'Ã  Sherbrooke/Longueil, puis marcher (5 min) jusque lÃ . Bon spot pour QuÃ©bec/Maritimes.
Take the metro to Sherbrooke/Longueil, then walk to this point (5 min). Good spot to QuÃ©bec city/Maritimes.

To Deer Lake/Corner Brook: try to begin to hitch there (and not in Norris Point for example).
Little traffic but it works.

Demander sur le traversier ou aux autos qui l'attendent.
Ask on the shuffle itself or to the drivers waiting .

Highway on-ramp, west towards Lac-Saint-Jean, east towards Chicoutimi. Waiting can be short or very long, it's a cast of dice. Listing as good anyways because it's the only suitable hitch location in JonquiÃ¨re.

From Metro Longueuil (yellow line), the best is to take bus 81. The bus will cross the highway, go further and come back, so just ask the driver. The walk is about 10 minutes. It's also possible to take bus 83, same thing, just a bit longer of a walk.
Never waited longer than 30 min.
Direction QuÃ©bec- waited less than a minute for a ride. Not great visibility but traffic is turning and moving slowly.
By the bus stop.. got a ride to the autoroute intersection (73) super-quick. Plenty of traffic and good visibility/space :)
Intersection with lights and far enough space to be seen and for cars to stop. Reasonable level of traffic, definitely ok to Trois-RiviÃ¨res
The spot is not bad except there is very low traffic. Luckyly locals are very helpfull
Lots of cool folks around here, including many hippie fruit pickers. North or south, this is a good spot.
To go west on 97, cars have to stop at a stop sign. This makes for a good hitching spot.
Very easy spot to get hikes to the airport. There is a nice hard shoulder that you can stand on. Drivers waiting at traffic lights can spot you easily. Experienced waiting time ca. 15 min.
I waiting a little bit to go to Sherbrooke but after it was ok.
very reliable spot to get a ride going south. generally a 30-90min wait for a ride
Decent spot, late in the evening traffic was scarce but eventually a trucker picked me up and drove me to the Baie-Comeau area. July 2025.

Good spot low traffic, cars can see you from far away also room to pull over for them.  If I had to do it again I would start walking north and just have my thumb out while I walk beats standing on the side of the road for hours like me. Bring lots of water and food. June 2025.

Decent spot, good line of sight for the drivers to see you also room to pull over. Traffic is scarce in the late afternoon, be prepared to be stuck for hours bring lots of water and sun protection. June 2025.
Good Spot. Heading North towards the viking place minimal traffic but the locals always help you out with rides.
Good Spot, heading south towards Rocky Harbour. July 2025.
Not the best spot in the world but it works, got a gas station close by to if need be. July 2025.
Good spot, make sure you wake up early so you can catch people heading to work, I missed that opportunity but still made it out pretty quick all things considered. July 2025.
Good spot, low traffic, heading towards trout river, got picked up by a local. If need be you can just walk into trout river.
Low traffic but good spot.
Good spot, low traffic but got a ride from a local all the way to the green gardens hike.
Decent spot with a good view, traffic was low but the locals around here were great Never went more than a car or two before being picked up. Was heading back to the main highway. July 2025.
Set myself up across from the air plane museum got a ride fairly quickly, cars are going slower through gander so this is a good spot. July 2025.
Good spot, good shoulder, straight stretch, took a while to get a ride here but that was my luck. July 2025.
Straight stretch, decent shoulder. July 2025.
Decent amount of traffic got a 30 minute ride out of town and the stood on the highway thumbing
good spot right here lots of room to pull over next to the comfort inn

The Spot is not bad for hitchhiking towards the south (North Bay), cars are going slow enough and there is a wide shoulder. Got stuck there for a day anyways, but there is an ESSO Gas station opposite where I was lucky to get a ride all the way to Montréal. The street through Matheson going east is used frequently by people coming from Route 11 and going to Quebec / Montréal.

Hitching East, this was an okay spot. Your best shot is probably talking to people making a stop at the coffee shop across the street, that's how I got a ride to Timmins. Be aware that the road going east will be leading thru 2.5 hours of nothing, with often no reception. I was told some hitchhiker disappeared here in 2025.
reasonable spot to go east. Traffic goes quite slow and enough room to pull over. Got a ride to Longlac. Not much traffic tho, on a Saturday.

Got stuck in Medicine Hat for a day. The spot is quite good, lots of room to pull over and cars are going slow. Got a ride to Dunmore the first day, where I got stuck and had to hitch back. Day 2 was the lucky one, after 1h wait a guy took me all the way to Manitoba. Don't give up!
waited about 45, room for cars to pull over on shoulder, cops didnt seem to care, got a ride straight to montreal
waited about an hour, room for cars to stop/pull into the gas station. cops drove by didnt seem to care
okay spot, got dropped here. People are going quite slow and there is a bit of space to pull over. Not much traffic, makes it easier. Were lucky to get a ride to Valemount.

It's a nice slow spot, with good room and visibility, but 99% of the traffic here is going to the Res. (Local traffic). If you're hitching through you might want to take the bus ($2.50) out to the bridge / res turn off, and hitch from there.
What little through traffic that there is, is mostly bikes & RVs.

This is the last town before Lilooet, but from what I could see the traffic volume is extremely low.

I didn't have a lot of time to wait, so I ended up turning around and taking the Tra
Hitching east on hwy-6 this is probably the best spot. There's good visibility, and enough room for vehicles to pull off.
Traffic volume on this highway is pretty low, but the percentage of drivers willing to stop is pretty high. I got picked up pretty late in the day and got a ride all the way to Nakusp.

We came here after the failure of hitchhiking 200m before on highway (see other post).
Few cars passing but they will take you! (we were heading east)

C'est un excellent lieu si vous voulez voyager vers le Saguenay/Lac-St-Jean. Il y a un arrêt, donc ça oblige les chauffeurs à s'immobiliser, et ils vont vous voir. Le seul hic, c'est que le trafic est relativement limité sur cette entrée d'autoroute.

There's a place for vehicles to pull off, and great visibility. There is still a little bit of local traffic, butout here you're past most of it. I got a ride in less than an hour on a slow Saturday morning.

There's a huge pullout over here. Grand Forks can be hit or miss, but this spot is probably your best bet for heading east. unfortunately I only got a ride to Christina lake the last time I went through here.

There is a lot of traffic going back and forth between here and the Teck Metals plant in Trail.
This spot is pretty good, but it does put you on the wrong side of the Jersey barrier. That said there is plenty of room for cars to pull off.
I didn't know what to expect here. It's a pretty fast spot. But, there's room to pull off and people seem to stop.

I got trafic of people coming from the town and the camping street and I was in front of the post office, so at the end the delivery guy from Post office gave me a ride to Sooke. After from Sooke there is public bus to Victoria ;)

Decent spot outside a commercial area. Visibility good, enough room to pull over, and low speed as it's right after a traffic light. Took a long long time because we were 2 women traveling and Vernon is a bit of a pain to hitch out of :-) Ride did not take us far, but was enough to keeo the morale up.

Got a ride super quick. All the highway through-traffic goes through here, with some cars coming from the off-ramp from Gasoline Alley. Excellent visibility, room to pull over.
*On a highway though, so be careful.*

Next-best spot out of Leduc as it has lots of traffic. Side of the highway has decent visibility and room to pull over. Only 2 lanes wide here, so easier for drivers to switch over. Not ideal because it is on a highway!
Sorti mon pouce sur la bretelle d'autoroute de Chateaugay à Salaberry. Picked up in 20 minutes or so. Ended up in St Thimothy , on the way to Salaberry
If you get stuck in Brooks, this is a good spot to get out of there. Truck drivers most likely are going to Medicine Hat
Short walk up the hill, way better spot than down in the city. Big shoulder.
Not a bad spot. Not a huge shoulder but traffic is light and slow so people can stop. People in this area will probably stop for you. Got a ride to castlegar
Got a ride to Freddy from here pretty quick.

Waiting here with a sign "Hwy 17 West" - few cars stopped in front of the Esso (asking at the petrol station didnt work so well). Most offered a ride to Sudburry, which was nice but we wanted to stay on the Highway. After half an hour a young couple travelling to BC picked us up and gave us a ride on Hwy 17 to Espanola where we wanted to go

Best way to go west from Chilliwack. There isn't much space, but traffic is slow enough to stop easily. Problem can be that there is too much traffic and they don't see you early enough, but it shouldn't be too long before the right one comes.
Plenty of space (got a ride from a truck), but traffic is low
Good spot, and it's possible to get trucks that are just getting on the highway from the truck stop since they are still at low speed.

Easy to get into the park: indigenous people from the reserve are pretty nice and took me all the way to the park gate. Note that hitchhiking is illegal in Pukaskwa national park, but you can ask people in the campground to get rides out of there.

Spot is beside the "Pines shore road" sign. You can also ask at the restaurant but I didn't need to
Big pick up with trailer was able to stop there, plenty of space. If in the Soo, it can be good to get a short ride there to find a longer ride afterwards

Better to get a ride while on the ferry but this is a good spot right off it. Trucks can't stop there but there are 2 lanes of traffic + the parking of the restaurant, enough for cars to stop. Gotta get there fast once the ferry arrives, because after that there won't be traffic.

Good spot, lots of traffic, high visibility and frequent traffic light changes. 
Most of the traffic isnt going far, so only got a short stop to Strathmore.
Definitely follow other reviewers advice about the side of the road to stand on.

Tried hitching a ride on the right side of the road in front of the traffic light with a sign saying "east", 1h no luck. Then a friendly driver told me to stand on the left side of the eastward traffic, on the traffic island there, because the two leftmost Lanes go mostly eastward and the right lane goes North and west. Was lucky in 30 more minutes. Great spot to stop in front the traffic light, loads of room there.
I was unable to get a ride east. After 1h, I stand at the red light across the junction instead and got a ride within seconds.
At the red light, I showed a sign to Regina and got a ride within seconds to Strathmore.
There is a strip mall to the north of the intersection, with a laundromat. Standing here you will get a lot of Stoney trail traffic, but its less of a walk. Better for later in the day.
The spot works... but there´s a ton of traffic and it´s not very chill. No traffic lights anymore.
worked well for me because you have the slow traffic merging onto the highway who have time to look at you and read your sign

Get to the last set of traffic lights on the no 1 road (The Trans-Canada road) going west from Calgary, just facing the Canada Olympic Park. Walk another 200 meters to the point where it splits, and stand between the road going straight (road no. 1) and the road going right. You're trying to catch a ride on road no. 1. A little spooky, but took me 15 minutes only with a big sign.
cars are going fast, room to stop though, quick pick up got a ride past edmondston
