I got dropped off just there, so had to try my chances. Got a ride quickly, there's safe place to pull over. It's not legal though.

The mood in Osoyoos felt pretty hostile. This place is definitely not what it used to be. I ended up taking the bus to Penticton

They've installed a curb along this section of the road, so there isn't a great place for folks to pull off until the next intersection.

If you're going north from here you might be better off taking the bus. BC Transit runs from here to Penticton a few times a day during week days.
If you want to get out of Osoyoos north is probably your best bet. This road has plenty of places to turn off and the best traffic volume in the area.
Didn't have any trouble here, having a sign helped and I got a ride almost immediately. Express bus gets you there from downtown.
If you're heading south the city bus goes as far as Peachland.
dreadful
High speed traffic, but space on the shoulder. Pretty easy to get to by bus, but there is some walking to do.
took 15 min at about 6 pm in middle of august, got a rid to Moose Jaw where I camped the night
Few people stopped to offer a ride , all short distances , got a ride to outside of oshawa

I was hitchhiking here with my thumb and spent there more than 20 minutes in cold wind. Most of the traffic coming to this intersection is bound for Toronto so I decided to walk to the east intersection with this Highway at east part of Oshawa, got lucky there.

Take the go train to Oshawa and walk onto the highway ramp. Ignore the no pedestrian/bike signs. Ask the driver, if they aren't going too far, if they can drop you of at an onroute. Got a direct ride to Montreal from the next onroute station.

Would be a more suitable spot if it were not closed for construction. Ended up walking toward the highway where I was picked up after about 45 mins. High speed, too many lanes, poor visibility. No other suitable spots or bus routes nearby. Make sure it's open before you go!
Despite a good sign and being looking very clean and smiley ... I waited almost 2 hours by -4°C to get a ride to Nisku where I got a ride to Calgary in a poor hitchhiking spot.. It is all about luck!

Good ramp, lots of space to pull over. Good traffic, but few people stops despite a good sign and being looking very clean and smiling ...
I waited almost 2 hours by -4°C to get a ride to Nexus where I got a ride to Calgary in a poor hitchhiking sport.. It is all about luck!
Standing at traffic light is the best option.
Good spot to go west from Medicine Hat. Right past the coffee stops, and after traffic lights, uphill, with wide shoulders. Took me 15 minutes with a sign.
A quick stop where a guy drop me furthur down at oshawa as im normaly heading to montreal !

The guy who picked me up did not know what hitchhiking was, I had to explain. He took me to Ajax out of desire to help, telling me that the neighborhood is only ethnic people and that they dont tend to "get" what I was doing. The driver was from Sri Lanka. I don't even think my explanation made sense for him in the end.
Plenty of space to stop and passing on ramp, but nobody seemed to care, so it seems like it's mostly metropolitain traffic.
Not really a good place but definitely do-able. I waited 30 minutes before getting a ride out to near the T.C.H.
No clue how a car could stop here. Maybe I'm not innovative enough.
Stand here with a sign "T.C.H." to go west. Make sure that your driver drops you ON the Trans-Canada Highway (there's a gas station just after Pitts Memorial Hwy joins TCH)
The second time I tried I was stopped by the police and told to leave the highway. So apparently it's not the best place...
After 15 minutes got a ride for 3 hours to Rimouski. Was raining though :)
Direction east. Lots of traffic, cars not so fast, fairly good place to pull over. And doesn't look illegal.

I tried to hitch before the gates, had no luck, than 20 minutes before scheduled departed started asking people waiting for the ferry and got a ride pretty quickly. Ask and you're gonna get it. Staff didn't mind me.

I had little luck hitching outside the gate where cars pay (and missed the first ferry after I arrived as a result), but got a ride once I moved into the food/waiting area and sat there with my sign (staff did not seem to mind although YMMV).  Once onboard, the ferry is also a good place to look/ask around for a better onward ride.

Schedules and fares can be found at http://www.nfl-bay.com/northumberland-ferries-schedule-and-fares/ .  The vehicle fare includes all passengers while the walk-on f
We had no luck hitching onto this ferry, and ended up buying tickets. Worth a shot, though.
That has nothing to do with th spot tho
Creepy old man tried to fuck me. I'ma dude too...
Not much space for people to stop, but I waited about 5 minutes there on a Sunday morning with an "Ottawa" sign and got a ride past Kingston.
There is not enough (legal) space for the cars to spot unless they block others right behind them. Bad spot in my opinion!
Not much space and the cars are fast, but still got a ride within 30minutes
Good junction, but cars are going quite fast from the South

Relatively good spot if you are going from Lillooet to west.
Or you can try it go to gas station (800m farther)

Lot's of tourists, but in most cases are full or are from asia (thus they don't stop). Got a ride in less than half an hour.
Went from Skyline trail.
Lot's of cars passing, but fast and only narrow shoulder.
Not the best place at all (not so much room to pull over and cars are passing slightly fast), but got a ride after 20 min.
2h waiting time as a very qiet area with very low traffic , didnt choose the spot as been droped off her from toronto as going toward montreal , then a truck pick me up all towar my destination !
Sunday morning 10am got a ride at 12:00 a bit normal as it wass sunday 10 july almost 20 car within the 2h then a truck took me up to wonowone  , like 101 miles

So arrived by 3 pm wass my aim for the day but as im heading to alaska i thought i have time to keep going more north so ended up at dawson creek , but thus lift took me to Mc leod lake then from their to another lift !
Not a bad place, managed to get a ride in like 20 mins even in very late afternoon - all the way to North Bay
Seemed to be a good spot, with a lot of traffic, but no one picked me up for 3 hours to go West, so i moved.
I hitchhiked to Victoria and this was my first every spot. Lot's of cars going to Kanata,30 minute ride.You see federal workers need some fun in their daily 9 to 5 commute
if you wanna go to USA your best best in this area is through cornwall,not 1000 island bridge
to hitchhike to Toronto this is the best way from Ottawa. Yes Ottawa/Toronto drivers are mostly dicks but if you look like a student and clean you should be able to hitch a ride in under 30 minutes.
try Private cars, it's gonna be tough crossing the border, and your driver is gonna have to help u. U can't walk across the border *(they may let you across if you have a bike)
I asked to be dropped off here as I was heading to Thunder Bay and didn't want to go through the town.
Not the best spot as cars come at full speed, but there is enough space to pull over and drivers can see you well in advance.

Worse border crossing ever in both ways! US patrol officier found my blog address in my backpack and went online to read it. He also read my journal. I got denied entrance because he found some comments about minor offences while I was in California...
Watch out!
I hitchhiked from the visitor center parking lot. I got a ride to East Surrey within 30 mins.
Waited 50 minutes for a ride, took me all the way to Antigonish.

Got a ride to Nisku within 20 minutes, but I think I just got lucky. The traffic is going fast although there is lots and lots of room to safely pull over. Getting there is just a tad tricky. You'll have to walk 3-4 km in order to get there.
A little fast, but you'll be seeing traffic from the East and West of the CIty.
Heading to Jasper wait time was about an hour. Shoulder is wide but semi-trucks are not allowed on this road and traffic is sparse. The road is very beautiful!!

Hitchiking to Edmonton, wait time was about an hour. Shoulder is narrow. Had more luck when I moved down past the bridge further down the highway where there is a gravel clearing that has more space for people to stop.
like other post said, walk north out of town. there are some bad things said about a serial killer trucker.
I'm always walking, but if you stand in this spot just outside of the Tim Hortons you will find yourself with a ride within and hour.
After 2 hours got a ride to Fairbanks, which is not so bad, better than average here.

Hitching towards Alaska. Spot looks good, but it just doesn't work with all of these tourists in RVs. I walked out of the town and shouldn't have. Your better bet is trying to talk to some people at gas stations/restaurants.
Got lucky and after an hour of waiting got a ride to Whitehorse, they were going all the way to Fairbanks.

Hitching towards Alaska.

Pretty much the end of the town. A lot of tourists in RVs, but I don't have great experiences with them, it's harder to hitch a ride. After traffic lights cars are slow, drivers can see you and there's place to pull over.

However since tourists in RVs are not likely to pick you up, you can spend several hours here and I strongly recommend trying to talk to some people at gas stations, fast foods, etc. It's much easier.
Waited long, 2 hours, but managed to get a ride past Grand Prairie from here.

Hitching north towards Grand Prairie, the Yukon, Alaska. It's even called "Scenic Route to Alaska".

Just after a turn, so cars are slow, can see you and there's good place to pull over. However, traffic is really scarce...

Got dropped off here. Was expecting a really bad time, since the spot is not the best, but there's a lot of traffic and that's a plus. After 45 minutes a guy actually went back to get me as he didn't stop at first.

Hitching west towards Jasper, Grand Prairie (or Alaska :D ).

Not the greatest spot. Cars go fast, a lot of traffic, the road is straight, so drivers can see you, but the place to pull over is not so obvious. Possible though.

This spot used to be perfect before they finished the overpass. Now the traffic isn't slowed by a stop light, there's no good shoulder to pull off, and there's lots of merging and splitting going on. Anyone have a better place now?
The spot where people go up island. You can even see some on Street View :)
I got a ride out of here towards Toronto in about 20mins, with a sign.
Even with a good parking for cars to stop, no one for 3 hours ! Then a guy going toward Toronto, and then one going West (my savior !)

Plenty of trafic, which goes not too fast, and a good shoulder to pull. I used to bike there from Montreal and to lock my bicycle on Eiffel Street. Totally in the middle of nowhere though.

(beware the construction, this exchange was still under renovations in winter 2014)

Really close to a big gas station, convenience store and restaurant, but not that much trafic.

It's accessible by bus from Montreal by the 200 line linking St-Hyacinthe to Longueuil Subway Station via the 116 road.
Plenty of trafic and lot of space to pull, but people go a little fast. It's also in the middle of nowhere.
Go a bit up the road to get more traffic.
Good to try, but sometimes you just can't get it there ! If you are out of the business hours, that's still the best one you can have.

Easy to get a ride to Fermont, QC, then it gets more tricky as the road gets empty. Also some workers go around 50 km to Mont Wright, where there is a big mining complex. But I was lucky and after 4 rides and an hour of waiting in the middle of nowhere got a ride for over 500 km with a truck driver going all the way to Baie-Comeau, QC.

On this highway you can hitchhike basically everywhere. There's no traffic anyway, so cars can just stop on the road. Prepare for well over 500 km of gravel (as for 2014) to Happy Valley-Goose Bay.

The road is terribly empty (a car maybe every 15-30 minutes?) with an exception of the boat traffic passing around two times a day. A lot of people seems to be afraid of picking up people in the middle of nowhere, so I had to wait my time. Took me 5 rides until I got my long-awaited ride to Goose Bay
There is some decent place to pull over, a lot of traffic, but cars go fast. I was stuck here for over an hour in the evening, but the next morning the first car stopped.
I would have walked out to the hwy overpass. Most of the traffic at this spot is tourists and locals.
I waited here all morning, and as the morning progressed, more and more hitchhikers joined me to waste away the day. But if you get stuck in Hope heading east, you gotta do what you gotta do.
The traffic is low volume and mostly local, so Start early. The locals are pretty chilled, and in my experience mainly positive.
If you're heading west I would walk until the hill flattens out along the air strip, there are better places for cars to pull off.
Hitching east out of Osoyoos. There is a nice tall tree here for some shade. Get there early. Bring lots of water. There aren't many stores near by
Decent spot if heading west on the 97C.  There is lots of room to pull over, and since traffic is now splitting on those going southbound and those going west, no sign is needed.
Direction: ferry to Nova Scotia. Not a best spot, but didn't feel like crossing the bridge on foot (perfectly do-able though). Lots of traffic, but only a bit of space to pull over.
Direction Moncton. Cars very fast, but there's place to stop.
2 of us waited about 45 minutes. Cars are fast, there's no much place to stop, but still after enough time someone will pull over. Whole Trans-Canada traffic goes here.
Going East, took a local bus and walked a bit to get there. Been picked up pretty quiclky for a short ride.
We were heading to Montreal. Lot of traffic here going in our direction but we've had to wait a long time to get a 30min ride
across from a gas station, good place to pull over.  i got a ride all the way up to mt carleton from here, started early in the morning and had time to hike it that day.

Ended up stranded near Rigaud, and spent a night underneath an overpass. Luckily in the morning, a car stopped for us as we were walking along the autoroute (which is illegal, but there was little traffic coming from the off-ramps). In the future, I would try to just get a direct ride to Ottawa from Hudson Inn.

Ottawa to Mtl
Started late and got stuck here at night. Waited 1h at the ultramar gas station asking drivers, most of them were local rides, or going West. Finally got a ride around 11pm to get to Dorval.

Going East, waitied 30 min here, nothing, then decided to walk on the HWY, where i got more luck.
There is some good trafiic and enough space to pull over but ...
Guy alone with a big backpack.

Got a ride after Hiking in the Johnston Canyon, cars are not really regular but could pick you up pretty easily !
Got a ride to Lake Louisse with a local driver around 6pm on friday, in winter.
Picked up a Czech who had waited 3 hrs near the gas-station junction. It's a good-sized journey from here to Dease Lake;.
Dropped here coming from Saskatoon took me almost 2h to have a ride to Edmonton but it was almost dark (on wednesday)
Dropped here coming from Winnipeg, waited almost 1 hour to have a direct ride to Regina
Perfect place to hitchhike, good visibility, easy for cars to park, got a direct ride for Sudbury in 30-40 minutes.
2 hours to get a ride to Rolphton (West)  but it was almost at night.
A good spot for the car to stop but no one stoppped for 2 hours !
Quite fast, but worked well.
High speeds, but major interchange.
Low traffic going short distances.
Most traffic won't be going very far.
Best try at edge of town, while speeds are too fast on Hway.
on ramps, low traffic going North and South, but speeds are low.
Gas station, truck stop
To Fredericton, after reaching the TCH from Place Champlain

A fair bit of traffic heading onto the Route 1 freeway near here.  I got a ride from this spot to beyond St George within about 20 minutes.  The driver who picked me up claimed that it was legal and better to hitch on the freeway itself north of here, so that might be worth a try too.
This Irving Big Stop is a good place to hitch westwards if you can get someone to drop you here.
After the traffic light is a decent spot to hitch eastwards, though there is still quite a bit of local traffic.

Good spot towards Trois-Rivières and Montréal using A-40. If you don't get a ride, you can take a local bus from there and hitch from one of the gas station spots on Charest, where people are more used to seeing hitchhikers.
Hard to explain why but took a very long time to get a lift south towards Maine. Waited 3 hours on a rainy morning and got to Saint-Come..

South to Saint-Georges.

Not ideal as southbound traffic takes the left-hand lane, whilst the hitcher must take a right. i got a ride fairly quickly, but only as far as the other side of Pont de Québec, which wasn't ideal for getting back on the 73.

Goobies Gas Station.
This for some reason is a tradition for many Newfoundlanders to stop and eat at the Big Irving Gas Station here - notable by it's Moose Statue in the parking lot. While not shown on the hitchwiki map, this is a junction. Highway 210 heads off toward the south coast of Newfoundland here.
Not great but likely the best spot out of Clarenville heading Northwest. This is the main road in and out, nearest fast food and coffee.
Nice spot to hang around and wait for a lift (you have to have sign here). Waiting time on a Sunday is awful (about 2,5 hours) but this is balanced out by the breathtaking landscape.
Not very nice to hitchhike but it is just a matter of time to get a lift here. In my case it took over an hour but the guy who took me drove me over 200 km northbound.

It's good for north or south on the main highway. I see lots of other hitchhikers here. The mall, gas station, fast food and some hotels are near the highway here. Head toward which ever side of town you are going out of. You can walk from end to end along the highway here in 20min. You can make a stop if need be without straying from the highway too.
Northwards. People generally have place and time to stop (especially when it's snowing).

Stephenville has a Pop. of 8000 It's mostly a college town. Rides mostly go Northwest to Corner Brook. This is a junction. There are no gas stations or anything around here, but you can camp without permits in many places around Newfoundland. Wait time depends. Most traffic to/from Corner Brook is early morning and in evening for Stephenville people working in Corner Brook. Port aux Basques Ferry times also affect traffic to the Southeast of this area.
Alternatively you can get a shuttle van to
Southwards. be carefull, there's nothing around! If someone's going to Stephenville from Corner Brooke, ask for being dropped there if possible.
Low Traffic to reach Lac-Sergent, feasable with the locals only
Make sure you stick to the urbanised zone and that you get a ride direct to Shannon
Potential good spot for local traffic to St-Basile and beyond to Cap-SantÃ© (A-40)
Still in sprawled urban area, but cars can pull over by the different shops entrance (on top of the Hill), direction South
Direction East to Ste-Catherine, it is better to stick at the crossroad
Heading West, you will probably get a ride to  Le Bic from there. Just hitch in front of the supermarket, there is a street light and a place where cars can safetly stop.
Service station is you are heading East.
Spot to hitch out of Charlottetown towards Souris, and the Magdalen Islands.

Northward: Local traffic but there is possibility one of the few car will stop. If you are heading to St-Basile, stay by the ramp so that industrial truck can coming slowly from the highway can stop for you
The gas station at Mt Robson Provincial parc can potentially be a good spot for getting far distances (to the west). Always a lot of people that stay there several days, so be patient!
Like most of the Alaska highway: very hard! Most of the vehicules are big American RV's!
Pretty hard, get out of the village, so you avoid locals. A lot of people only go to the mines (a few km from Dawson) very early in the morning.
Potentially a good place to get in Alaska, because nearly all cars who take this boat, go to Alaska
Pretty well place to get up north. People stop more easely because they know that you are a backpacker. It's also the last gaz station for several 100 of km. Count in a few hours anyway.
Take the bus from Moncton to this place, otherwise too much local traffic.
Tried asking people for rides at this big gas station, but they threatened to call the police on us. Still managed to sneakily get a ride though ;)
More scenic than the main highway, but less traffic. Took us quite a bit longer than it should have. At least the berries on the side of the road were in season!

For hitchhiking westward on the Trans Canada, it's as good as it gets in Thunder Bay... Not brilliant, but the only place on the way out of town where you get enough shoulders for cars to conviniently pull over. It's only a 10 meters strech, so pay attention: it is after the traffic light, right in front of the Canadian Tire. As a bonus, the Canadian Tire gardening shed is out in the open, they just clear it before it closes on 22:00, then you can stay there for the night... Especially handy for

Pour aller vers Ottawa/Toronto. Pas terrible mais seul spot Ã  ma connaissance.
Towards Ottawa/Toronto. Average but only spot I know.
Northwards. be carefull, there's nothing around! If someone's going to Stephenville from PaB, ask for being dropped there if possible.

Vers Tadoussac. Beaucoup de trafic mais peu de place pour s'arrÃªter.
Towards Tadoussac. Much traffi but little place to stop.
friendly safe haven esp in bad weather (it gets cold here), 'Wits End'at Riverside Motel,Hadashville, MB  on transcanada hwy
Hitch mostly anywhere on Mgr Langlois to get out of Valleyfield towards the HWY 20.

Takes HOURS to walk here, but its the only reasonable off ramp heading east from Saint John. There is a bus that will give you a head start, though.  Perfect shoulder, and you get traffic coming from the north also with a stop sign so they can scope you out before turning.
Gas station close to a stoplight. Average location because loads of local traffic + people whom want to pick you up have to park in the gas station.
Got a ride in about 2 minutes to St-Georges de Beauce.. not for the faint of heart though, and presumably illegal. I won't be standing there again in a hurry!
"route du Roy" (138) towards QuÃ©bec city. Take bus no2 to Sanctuaire (end station) and walk 5-10 minutes. Spot ok, but very low long distance traffic, mostly hopping from village to village
To North-East (Drummondville). Enough space ang good visibility. But not so high traffic and seemingly very local
On the on-ramp towards North-East (Drummondville). Cars are just starting to speed up. Just enough space to stop.
Plenty of space and good visibility, but low traffic at times

Northbound, this is probably the best spot in a bad town. (Prince George has a problem with serial killers killing hitchhikers, so most people will think you're crazy.) Across the street is the last gas station in town, so lots of people going north with stop. Odd, crazy locals, nice gas station workers.
North to Prince George, this isn't such a terrible spot. Beautiful scenery, no nearby drinking water, though.
Slow hitching here, but heading north to Prince George, it may be your best option. There's a stoplight, room to pull over, and a gas station with bathrooms and water.

US Border control. If you try hitchhiking from Canada the best thing to do is walking across the border from White Rock and start hitchhiking behind the border control.

Nobody likes to bring foreigners across the border.
Difficult to go out to Montreal, because everybody got to L'Ã®le aux Soeurs and dont go to Sherbrooke
Cars are scarce. Anywhere along this stretch is good. Go check out the local museum while your here. July 2025.

Anywhere along this stretch is a good spot to wait traffic is low so they can just stop on the road no problem make sure you start early in the morning though, the bugs were bad but I brought a bug net and long clothing so they were manageable make sure you do the same. June 2025.

Just walking with my thumb out, got a ride to L'Anse-au-Clair pretty quickly, was late in the evening so low traffic. Make sure you try to get a ride before or on the ferry, the good part of this ferry was they let me off first but nobody from the ferry picked me up. Bring lots of sun, bug, and wind protection also lots of water and food if you plan on hitching through Labrador. July 2025.

I stood at the bottom of the first hill, going north. Not the best spot in the world since the cars are going fast around the corner and  don't have much time to stop. If your on this stretch make sure you start early so you can catch people heading to work. Bring lots of water and sun protection. June 2025.
Good spot lots of room to pull over was here in the late afternoon, low traffic got picked up eventually after a few hours. June 2025.
Bring lots of water and sun protection. You will be waiting for hours out in the sun with no protection other than with what you bring or clouds. June 2025.
Not the best spot in the world but it is what it is, make sure you start early in the morning so you can catch workers and travellers going west. July 2025.
On the highway, long straight stretch gives the  cars lots of time to see you. July 2025.
Decent room for cars to pull over. They are going fast but gotta make due with what you have. July 2025.
Not a bad spot. Somewhat decent room for cars to pull over that are coming from the on ramp but can't say the same for the ones already on the highway. July 2025.

I didn't actually hitch this spot. I was in a pitch so I booked a poparide instead. However, I walked past this spot and it's the perfect place for northbound rides. Visibility is perfect, open, plenty of space to pull over, and the vehicles won't be going too fast when they see you.
Not a lot of traffic, can stand on the on-ramp and highway. Got a ride to fredricton though, seems like most are going long distances
Waited about an hour. Not a lot of traffic. Might get lucky though
good spot to hitch a ride has lights so people are going by slow

Not great.
Was lucky to get a ride late in the evening, probably thanks to the street lights being there. 
Did not get very far though.
not alot of traffic coming through here, ended up getting lucky and being driven down to grandfalls for a more popular spot

Timmins is a not so great place to hitch out of, going east. No shoulders to stop anywhere. The ESSO Gas station is quite busy, more than the Shell opposite, so I was lucky to get a short lift to Matheson.

Got picked up here before I could even put my thumb out, which was lucky. Got a ride to Winnipeg.
Cars go partially slow after the Traffic Light and there is room to stop. Before that, I asked around at the nearby Esso and Shell Stations, but to no avail.

I was told lots of people on the way from Regina to Winnipeg stop here at the A&W for coffee, especially commuters in the morning.

Was too late for that, and I asked around at the Gas Station and got a ride east to Brandon there. Thumbing on the side of the road (Speed Limit 80, before the traffic light) didn't succeed.

I was standing on a different corner of this intersection until someone rolled down their window and suggested this spot because the truckers segue straight to the TCH. I did just that and after 1-2 hours a trucker slowed. It's a good spot because the traffic light has a short cycle so the queue gets backed up and cars can see you while waiting for the green light
Lots of traffic, but the wait time is surprisingly long, nobody wanted to stop. Shoulder is wide enough only if you go west. Beautiful view.
Not a lot of traffic. Wide shoulder. Right after traffic lights cars are slow which is good. Got a short ride to the closest overpass.

On paper this spot kind of sucks. It's kind of a suicide lane, but I for some reason I have good luck here.

Most of the traffic that you'll see here are pulling off to go to bridle falls waterpark. 

That said, try not to get dropped off here. If you get stuck there are some convenience stores, about a 10 min walk away.

5/5 durant le festif de baie St-Paul 
Il y a un bon trafic en général
Not the best location to do the hitchhiking , need to go further up to the hwy 212 according to the person who picked me up

Hitching south out of Sicamous is hard. I was very fortunate as a solo female traveler to have someone pick me up. This spot has decent through-traffic, slow speed and room to pull over. Only trouble is nobody in Sicamous wants to pick you up :-) Wait time was a while. Stay here for easy access to food/plugs/water at the restaurants up the road if you can't get a ride.

Take the 108 bus to the soccer field nearby, walk to the back of the soccer field and hop the fence/gate. Highway shoulder was closed for construction when I went, so getting a ride was difficult. Decent room to pull over otherwise. Lots of on-ramps leading here, so drivers aren't quite at highway speeds yet. Went EBD to Sicamous with a truck driver.
Quiet time of the day on the 16. 2 people pulled over as well but would've only taken me down the road but I decided to stay by the gas station and didn't wait too long after the first 2.

Gave it a 3star as it was raining all night and there's just enough of an eave for me to nap where it's dry. Sign was for thunder bay and Winnipeg, I said it's good.. it's the route I want anyway. Unexpected as I was just eating when the guy pulled in front of me.
Westbound ramp coming from the south. Waited forever on the opposite side. Guy saw my sign, stopped and said I'm actually going to north bay
Took a while to get a ride, but it was early in the morning. Got to Salmo
Got picked up by a guy in a camper bus who took me all the way to BC

We wait here 4 hours... Maybe bad luck because the spot was good with a gas station and the 2 roads for the east (the 11 for the North and the 17 for the south). More people are going throu the north. Nipigon is a good place to sleep (free campground in the marina).

Hitching east out of Creston sucks. 99% of the traffic you'll see is local. This spot isn't great but it's kind of your best option.
There is a set of lights to slow traffic down, and a parking lot for cars to pull off the road. Local traffic usually turns off at this intersection.

Getting here was damn painful - loads of construction on/around the on ramps people typically use to hitch out. Otherwise decent spot - lots of room to stop and lots of through traffic, esp. on weekends in the summer (people going to Banff).
I don't remember the exact spot, It was at gaz station for sure. Cars are going fast at the exit of La Baie St Paul be careful
Good spot to leave Québec toward Charlevoix. There is a "stop" where you really have the time to make eye contact with the driver !
Traffic is low and lots of local traffic, but there is space and the ride will come eventually.

Traffic light. Limited space for stopping, but doable at red light. Lots of local traffic, might be good to get a ride to Redcliff for a better spot. Sign is very useful, TC motel has a cardboard dumpster if needed
Tons of space, low speed after the stop sign, but low traffic.
Ok spot, space for trucks to stop but you might wait a bit before someone stops
Not a specific spot, just walking along the road
This spot is kind of in the middle of nowhere, but I've had good luck here.

I hitchhiked with that guy several times down the road until we both got to Vancouver, we kept splitting up and then getting dropped off in the same place as each other! I seen him in the middle of downtown Vancouver by chance on the last day of my stay there. Small world!
Japanese hitch-hiker stood here for several hours going from the junction to Golden. Not relatively safe to slow-down/pull-over for hitch-hikers.
Long wait, but got a ride all the way to the soo
Don't wait here.  Go west down the highway to the university/granville road.

They just put in an overpass here. May make it better. Like most of the trans-Can it's hit or miss. The people around here can be kind of funny. I was flipped of by an old lady that could barely see over the steering wheel.
Waited for 4 hours, no ride. Clear day, clear spot just after traffic lights with ample room to pull over, yet no luck. Had to move faster so went and bought a bus ticket
Get there early in the morning - you'll go far!
Very good spot for hitchhiking. Good traffic and traffic lights so potentional drivers can spot you before giving you ride.
Toward Quebec: There isn't much space for a car to pull over and it isn't the most convenient spot but with patience you can catch a long distance ride
Got stuck here, but an older gentleman had pity on me :)

I waited here for 2 hours without succes. If you want to go East from Kelowna, it's better go through Hwy 97 (good spot is in Peachland, which is reachable by public trasportation)  to Osoyoos and after to Hwy 1.

Well not the best spot for me 3h40 min waiting time , wass heading to thunder bay but got a lift to my next destination to the Niagara falls , good spot thogh because car can see u well in advance and plenty of space to pull in , so i guess just bad luck ! Wass a hot days at 12am so the sun over me ive roasted like a chiken lol :-)
I guess u never have to give up , standed accros the road of the camping site for 5 hours , ended up having a ride all the way up to whitehorse as im heading to alaska !

Hitching from there to Mont-Joli, I suppose it's easier to hitch westward than eastward because of the way the ramp is made. When you try to avoid traffic going west, you're semi-legal but you won't wait much.
This ramp is mainly cars going to the nextexit when going West, and mainly construction trucks when going East. 1 hour then I left.
if you get dropped in between Prescott and ottawa, if it's not Kemptville you are probably in some entrance ramp where 1 car passes by every 30 minutes. This is when you go on the highway
to hitchhike to Toronto this is the best way from Ottawa. Yes Ottawa/Toronto drivers are mostly dicks but if you look like a student and clean you should be able to hitch a ride in under 30 minutes.
onramp unusable. highway too busy/windy for rides..
Do not stand as far outside of town as we did.

Location is conveniently accessible by public transport. I stood here for about an hour unsuccessfully waiting for a ride to Edmonton since most of the traffic is going to Airdrie. Easier to go there first if you need to go north.

shittiest place in all of canada for hitching. it had a bad reputation. almost better to walk down the highway a couple ks until you are on a flatter, straighter section. you will get a ride but it will take a couple days. bring warm clothes
Waited an hour in the evening, then camped in the woods nearby, woke up, waited 4 hours (!) and finally got a ride to Beaver Creek. One of my few worst hitchhiking spots in North America.

Hitching towards Alaska. Spot looks good, but it just doesn't work with all of these tourists in RVs. I walked out of the town and shouldn't have. Your better bet is trying to talk to some people at gas stations/restaurants.

I got dropped off here and was trying to bypass Hamilton, but wasn't successful. Waited 2 hours, 2 cars stopped, but were going just a few kilometers. Traffic very local. Oh, and some place to pull over, not great, but some.

***NOTE***
This on-ramp is closed until 2018
http://ottawaeast.ca/node/68
Logical spot for Quebec people heading towards Montreal. There isn't much space to pull over, so it's safer when there isn't much traffic. Still a lot of local traffic too, so the offer varies.
Almost no trafic at all.
Not a lot of trafic, and a long walk from anything...

Heading to Labrador City, direction west. Had a lot of troubles getting there. First got a ride fairly quickly, got dropped off in the middle of nowhere, waited 5 hours (!) and nothing happened. There was some traffic (a car 15 minutes maybe), but around 80% of them were workers' cars, who are not allowed to take other people with them. Had to camp, next morning got a ride to Churchill Falls in an hour.

I got stuck here for really long (around 3 hours), trying to hitch west to Trans Canada Highway. Empty road, especially in the evening (had luck next morning), most people going from Port Rexton turn to Trinity.
This hwy is super fast, busy, and there aren't really any good spots for cars to pull off. Your best bet is to stand at the lights.
Direction Hopewell Rocks. So much local traffic.. I gave up the spot and walked a few kilometers until I caught a ride.
It can take a long time to get a ride here, but it will probably take you all the way to Whitehorse when you do.

Traffic on the highway is probably too fast to stop for you.  There's a gas station here where you can get a ride eventually, but if you're going north you should probably try for a longer ride out of Fort St John rather than accepting one to here.
Not very much traffic on this part of the Yellowhead Highway.
Was stuck at this truck stop overnight, and didn't have much luck hitching on the road in front of it, but then got a ride from a trucker all the way to Winnipeg.
There's a fast food truck here, could try asking people eating.

Dropped on the ramp coming West (from Chilliwack) and going East, i started to walk to find a wide shoulder, showing my sign. Surprinsingly a van stopped on the way, it was barely wide enough and pretty sketchy but it did the job !
I guess from Hope u have some good lucks to go far, i got a direct ride to Banff !
Guy alone with a big backpack.

Towards rivière du loup.

Room to park, medium visibility but Almost no one taking this lane.
Waited for hours at the gas station/restaurant, i think it was bad luck, but i finally got a ride to espanola
Took me 3 hours to have a tiny ride to Laurentian Hills ...
i waited on thje ramp going West for 1h without any car to stop. Traffic is pretty low. Then i walked directly to the highway (witch is forbidden) and found a West ride in 15 minutes !
If dropped off here and going North, Strongly suggest walking to the next ramp further down. Very few cars going North here!
Cops bugging us and a long wait. Got a ride down the road a km or so to a petro station and had better luck there.

Stood here 1.5 days. Its called "Highway of Tears" because some 15 girls have been gone missing in the last few years while Hitchhiking. Finaly got taken by an American who had no idea. Worst spot in Canada to HH!
Took me and my gf over an hour both directions
Heading towards Matane, too many cars, too many locals, too fast, even with the street light.
Dormi en esta peuqeÃ±a estacion de servicio pq tome esta alternativa para no entrar en la ciudad. Por la maÃ±ana camine 10 km hasta la siguiente estacion de servicio
Easy to hitch, however there is nearly no traffic, it is more valuable to use a parallel Regional Road with more traffic.

every 15-60 minutes someone to the north (depending on the season). By far most of the people have to be in Kitwanga just at the other side of the bridge. to mention: hitchhiking next to a traffic sign "hitchhiking: is it worth the risk"
pretty rough to get in Stewart. You will have to hope for tourists! Be carefull for bears!
Very calm road, but this is probably the best place to go to fredericton from Fundy National Park. Camping next to it!

Try to not get stuck here. The shoulders are wide, but it's right on the highway, and cars are wooshing by 100km/h. There is a small cafe and restaurant + a garage, but the only people who stop there are locals, who usually won't bother to pick you up. I waited 4 hours (!) there, until a nice granny working there took pitty on me and took me 20 miles up the road to Blind river... So 20 miles / 4 hours, do the math.

Terrible. Waited 2 and a half hours in the rain, no one stopped. There are acouple of road stops and restaurants, but they sit right on the highway, which is a straight strech, so most vhicles woosh by like wind. I never got a ride standing next to the road, it was when I gave up and retreated to one of the coffee stops that a trucker spotted my sign, which I wouldn't count on. Conclusion: always carry your sign visible, you'd never know!
Few people go through this place. Anybody knows a good spot to leave Fredericton?

There are not that many places where to hitch from in Montreal, but heading towards Ottawa (40W) this might prove a good try. I got a ride in a truck going to Pointe Claire. Very good when there is a lot of traffic as people can see you in the distance. They were very surprised to see a hitcher there. It is a bus stop for bus 100, which you can board at CrÃ©mazie metro station.
Marked as bad because very little traffic, however most likely your best bet if busses 31 and 32 are not available.
Direction QuÃ©bec city. Little traffic only
Good visibility, restroom, drinkable water... but very low traffic, mostly touristic or very local!
Trying to get outta Winfield is a real pain in the ass; there's no shoulder.

Not a bad spot to wait, close to town and also room for cars to pull over they don't have much time to see you though after they make the turn in front of you. Make sure you have a big sign. July 2025.
Not a lot of space and time for the drivers to stop. Upside is you can hitch multiple ways at once. Eventually got a ride into stephenville. Bring lots of Water and food. June 2025.
Walking south with my thumb out. I wouldn't really waste my time standing still since traffic is low. Got picked up eventually and driven all the way to St barbe. July 2025.

Was just walking towards Norris Point with my thumb out, not a lot of traffic, and very windy roads with not the best of shoulders but you can make it work. Got picked up quickly by a local. July 2025.

This is the Big Stop, lots of truckers and a diner to eat with wife. It was sheer luck I got a ride as the dude that saw me missed his exit and circled back, and when he saw I was still waiting, he gave me a ride. Better luck with a trucker

Not a great place to stop. 
Fair bit of traffic along the highway, but most don't slow or stop at Indian head. 
Spent 4+ hours for a short ride not even to the next town.

This ramp is in the middle of nowhere, but at least there is some traffic. 

I was trying to hitch back to Chilliwack, but decided to walk to the next ramp instead. Try not to get dropped off here, it's in the middle of nowhere.
Most folks were headed into Edmonton. Managed to get about an hour down the highway

Great spot if you're going a short distance, to a smaller town slightly southwest or southeast. Had 5 cars stop all going not too far. Not ideal to go to Calgary/Red Deer. Most traffic to Calgary goes from Edmonton and does not stop here as it is too close by.
Took about an hour to get a ride here. It was pouring rain

Spot is a bit creepy, cars go quite fast and most are going to Toronto and not to Ottawa.
There is a gas station nearby but only for trucks, and it is not very busy. We were taken by a truck  at the station when he stopped for a break.

Ah, the infamous Wawa. The straight portion of the highway 17 presents a semi-reasonable place to hitch north simply due to it being the only spot with decent visibility - although few will stop due to highway speeds.
Not the best spot, even if we wait only 5 minutes, cars are driving fast and they don't have place to stop, I won't recommand it
Too much local traffic, few people are going back to the transcanada
Where it merges from 2 to 1 lane... Not a great place, but did get a short ride to a better spot in Goulais river
no space to pull over anymore gotta go about 2km down the road for a spot that vehicles can pull over
Not a great spot, but there isn't much better anywhere else. Ask people at the gas station, but there is still a lot of local traffic. To get to Winnipeg, get there early as it is a long drive

There's a gas station and enough space to pull over. Loads of traffic but it took me more than 4 hours to get a ride out of Thunder Bay. Mostly locals, I wouldn't hitch there again, try to find a better spot

They are upgrading the highway in this area. Hitching west out of Salmon Arm is next to impossible at this point. After I gave up, I notced that there is a city bus that takes you to the top of the hill and it looks like there is a hitchable spot up there, but I haven't tried it.

Whatever you do, try not to get dropped off here, as it is real easy to get stuck. Going west, walking to the edge of town is best because there is a long pullout where cars can stop. I ended up waiting a number of here, due to what I figure is a large amount of local traffic on this road. My ride took me to a gas station a little ways down the road that was a much better place to hitchhike from.
Nobody wants to pick me up. I wanted to walk across but they USA border cops denied my entry
Although this is the main highway going west, it's a poor spot to wait.  Go to Arthur Street or Dawson Road.
This stretch of road is expected to be redesigned
This high-speed road is too narrowed for traffic to even think of stopping, it is better to stay near Ste-Catherine or near the Highway

Kamloops is terrible to hitchhike through, if you are going west make sure to get a spot a ways before the city, as it is just a jungle of highway. I was dropped off at a off-ramp by a flying J gas station before town by a driver who used to hitchhike, it was a good spot.
We got stuck at this horrible intersection, trying to head north. No rides all day, and hardly any shade either. Kamloops is also crack city, careful if you have to camp here.
onramp unusable. highway too busy/windy for rides..
onramp unusable. highway too busy/windy for rides..

no good turnoffs from onramp... Would not recommend... I down this highway for about 3 hours, none of the onramps are safe to pull off, none of them after baseline have much traffic, and the road is moving too fast and too busy (even on weekdays) to use... Im considering trying to 7 or heading towards montreal and then down to kingston.. Ottawa/tornto drivers suck for hh..

Infamous place. I had a ride but he had engine problems and decided to pull in here. Long wait times, but not terrible. Maybe I got lucky with 3 hours. Still, best to get a ride going straight to Sault Ste. Marie/Thunder Bay.
This junction has the worst reputation to be dropped off it is better to do the Sault Ste.Marie - Thunder Bay ride in one shot... many people get stucks for days here.
Bad Junction to be as a foot pedestrian - Dangerous
Do not stop anywhere on this highway between the highway 40 and the highway 173
Local traffic only
Local Traffic only

Although a popular stop on the Montreal-Toronto way, the spot is straight on the highway and cars woosh by in insane speeds. However, long acceleration strech and wide shoulders, and one of the bussiest roads for trucks in North America! For hitchhiking to Toronto, position yourself by the highway itself with the intersection entrance on your left, so you're seen from both roads. Take caution though! Got a ride, from a truck, within 15 minutes, all the way to Toronto. Used a sign. Thanks Ross!
Could have been a decent location if people had room to park, but otherwise avoid this place.
Going west. This seems like a good spot but its very far from town/food/water so be ready. Traffic is scarce and bugs are bad as with most of Labrador. July 2025.

horrible spot don't use is a spot for cars to pull over but vehicles going to fast
